The mean values were from duplicate slots of three individual samples.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) A large number of AP sites are produced continuously by spontaneous depurination in mammalian cells (12.Nakamura J. Walker V.E. Upton P.B. Chiang S.-Y. Kow Y.W. Swenberg J.A. Cancer Res. 1998; 58: 222-225PubMed Google Scholar), leaving intact AP sites. Oxidative stress also induces labile ring-saturated pyrimidine adducts that result in intact AP sites by chemical depyrimidination. These intact AP sites are subsequently incised 5′ to AP sites by class II AP endonuclease. Most oxidative base lesions are also excised by bifunctional DNA glycosylases with AP lyase activity, which introduce 3′-AP sites. In addition, hydrogen abstraction directly induces both 5′- and 3′-nicked AP sites (8.Breen A.P. Murphy J.A. Free Radical Biol. Med. 1995; 18: 1033-1077Crossref PubMed Scopus (910) Google Scholar, 9.Von Sonntag C. The Chemical Basis of Radiation Biology. Taylor & Francis Ltd., London1987: 238-249Google Scholar, 10.Pogozelski W.K. Tullius T.D. Chem. Rev. 1998; 98: 1089-1108Crossref PubMed Scopus (977) Google Scholar). Therefore, a significant number of intact, 5′- and 3′-cleaved AP sites may be induced in cells under oxidative stress conditions. The present study demonstrated that oxidative stress predominantly induced 5′-cleaved AP sites in DNAin vitro and in vivo. Furthermore, 5′-nicked AP sites directly induced by ROS were efficiently released from the DNA backbone through β-elimination by putrescine, but not by β-pol (Fig. 5). In contrast, 5′-cleaved regular AP sites induced by heat/acid treatment followed by Exo III were efficiently excised by either putrescine or β-pol. These results indicate that the 5′-AP sites induced in vivo and in vitro by ROS are repaired differently than 5′-regular AP sites. In B-form duplex DNA, ROS most likely induce sugar lesions directly by abstraction of hydrogen atoms at the C-4′ or C-5′ position of deoxyribose (9.Von Sonntag C. The Chemical Basis of Radiation Biology. Taylor & Francis Ltd., London1987: 238-249Google Scholar, 10.Pogozelski W.K. Tullius T.D. Chem. Rev. 1998; 98: 1089-1108Crossref PubMed Scopus (977) Google Scholar, 11.Lafleur M.V.M. Woldhuis J. Loman H. Int. J. Radiat. Biol. 1981; 39: 113-118Google Scholar). Under aerobic conditions, hydrogen abstraction at C-4′ results in DNA cleavage to produce the 3′-phosphoglycolate terminus, the base propenal, and the 5′-monoester phosphate terminus. In contrast, under anaerobic conditions, hydroxyl radicals induce C-4′-hydroxylated abasic sites with an equilibrium between C-4′-oxidized aldehydic AP sites. Hydrogen abstraction at C-5′ has also been proposed to produce 5′-cleaved aldehydic AP sites under aerobic conditions (8.Breen A.P. Murphy J.A. Free Radical Biol. Med. 1995; 18: 1033-1077Crossref PubMed Scopus (910) Google Scholar, 11.Lafleur M.V.M. Woldhuis J. Loman H. Int. J. Radiat. Biol. 1981; 39: 113-118Google Scholar). These AP sites with an aldehydic moiety should be a substrate for β-elimination and are detectable by the ASB assay. Therefore, we hypothesize that the 5′-AP sites induced by ROS represent oxidized AP sites such as 5′-cleaved C-4′- or C-5′-oxidized AP sites. Whereas putrescine excised 5′-regular AP sites at 100 mm, β-pol efficiently cleaved 3′ to the 5′-AP sites at 80 nm. These results are in good agreement with the differences in the efficiency of cleavage of intact and 5′-nicked AP sites by putrescine (17.Lindahl T. Anderson A. Biochemistry. 1972; 11: 3618-3623Crossref PubMed Scopus (471) Google Scholar) and β-pol (18.Prasad R. Beard W.A. Strauss P.R. Wilson S.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 15263-15270Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (172) Google Scholar). A 49-base pair oligonucleotide duplex DNA (20 nm) with a single intact or 5′-incised AP site (10,000 lesions/106 nucleotides) was cleaved ∼50% by treatment with 200 and 5 nm β-pol, respectively, for 15 min at 37 °C (18.Prasad R. Beard W.A. Strauss P.R. Wilson S.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 15263-15270Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (172) Google Scholar). In contrast, we utilized long genomic DNA containing a much lower frequency of AP sites (20 lesions/106nucleotides), which appears to be a more biologically relevant frequency based on the number of endogenous AP sites (13.Nakamura J. Swenberg J.A. Cancer Res. 1999; 59: 2522-2526PubMed Google Scholar). Interestingly, β-pol excised the 5′-dRp (deoxyribose phosphate) moiety in long genomic DNA as efficiently as those in oligonucleotides at similar concentrations. These data suggest that β-pol efficiently recognizes and excises 5′-cleaved regular AP sites under physiologically relevant conditions. Aldehydic AP sites were relatively minor oxidative DNA lesions generated by the Fenton reaction in in vitro experiments, whereas these AP sites became one of the major oxidative lesions in genomic DNA from cells exposed to H2O2. Furthermore, 5′-cleaved AP sites were more persistent compared with oxidative base lesions in cultured cells after exposure to oxidative stress. As described above, putrescine, but not β-pol, efficiently excised 5′-AP sites induced by ROS. These data indicate that 5′-AP sites induced by oxidative stress are not repaired efficiently by cellular excision repair pathways. However, the results regarding the efficiency of repair by putrescine indicate that the lesions are potentially repairable through β-elimination by an amine moiety. It has been proposed that the amine residue Lys72 in β-pol forms a Schiff base intermediate with the AP site and cleaves 3′ to the AP site (19.Prasad R. Beard W.A. Chyan J.Y. Maciejewski M.W. Mullen G.P. Wilson S.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 11121-11126Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). The difference in dRp lyase activity between putrescine and β-pol for 5′-AP sites induced by ROS suggests that the amine moiety of Lys72 in β-pol may not efficiently reach the aldehydic moiety of 5′-nicked oxidized AP sites. This inefficiency might be explained as follows: 1) β-pol inefficiently recognizes these 5′-aldehydic AP sites induced by ROS; or 2) after β-pol recognizes 5′-oxidized AP sites, Lys72 in β-pol does not reach the aldehydic moiety of these AP sites due to structural difference of oxidized AP sites. Although 5′-nicked C-4′-oxidized AP sites induced by bleomycin followed by human AP endonuclease are excised by β-pol (20.Xu Y.-j. Kim E.Y. Demple B. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 28837-28844Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar), the excision efficiencies of β-pol for 5′-nicked C-4′- or C-5′-oxidized AP sites directly induced by oxidative stress are still unknown. We hypothesize that 5′-oxidized AP sites directly induced by ROS may be repaired by the Flap endonuclease-1-dependent long patch base excision pathway. In our previous study, we found large numbers of endogenous 5′-nicked AP sites in rat tissues and human liver (13.Nakamura J. Swenberg J.A. Cancer Res. 1999; 59: 2522-2526PubMed Google Scholar). Interestingly, the cleavage fractions of AP sites induced by the Fenton reaction are similar to those of endogenous AP sites in rat and human tissues. Although it has been believed that AP sites are efficiently repaired, oxidized AP sites are not excised as efficiently as regular AP sites in cells. Therefore, we believe that endogenous AP sites arise primarily from oxidized AP sites rather than from regular AP sites. We suggest that the high steady-state level of AP sites might be due to an inefficient short patch base excision repair pathway by β-pol. It was originally demonstrated that β-pol required MgCl2for dRp lyase activity (21.Matsumoto Y. Kim K. Science. 1995; 269: 699-702Crossref PubMed Scopus (645) Google Scholar). However, Prasad et al. (18.Prasad R. Beard W.A. Strauss P.R. Wilson S.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 15263-15270Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (172) Google Scholar) proposed that β-elimination by β-pol is Mg2+-independent based on inhibition of dRp lyase activity by EDTA and restoration of dRp lyase function by supplementing with NaCl. Our results also showed that Ca2+, instead of Mg2+, quite efficiently excised dRp moieties from the DNA backbone. These data indicate that Mg2+ in not an essential cofactor for the dRp lyase activity of β-pol. The human enzymes counteracting most oxidative base lesions are bifunctional DNA glycosylases such as human 8-hydroxy-2′-deoxyguanine-DNA glycosylase and human endonuclease III (22.Aspinwall R. Rothwell D.G. Roldan-Arjona T. Anselmino C. Ward C.J. Cheadle J.P. Sampson J. Lindahl T. Harris P.C. Hickson I.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 109-114Crossref PubMed Scopus (252) Google Scholar), leaving 3′-AP sites after releasing modified bases. Subsequently, class II AP endonuclease removes the 3′-blocked termini by 3′-phosphoesterase activity to create a 3′-OH group for DNA repair synthesis (3.Demple B. Harrison L. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1994; 63: 915-948Crossref PubMed Scopus (1282) Google Scholar). Although ROS induce significant numbers of oxidized base adducts, there was no accumulation of the combined fraction of intact and 3′-nicked AP sites in cellular DNA after exposure to H2O2. These data suggest that class II AP endonuclease efficiently excises a large number of 3′-cleaved AP sites. In in vitro repair assays, 8-OH-dG and oxidized pyrimidines were repaired mainly by a short patch base excision repair pathway (6.Dianov G. Bischoff C. Piotrowski J. Bohr V.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 33811-33816Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar,7.Fortini P. Parlanti E. Sidorkina O.M. Laval J. Dogliotti E. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 15230-15236Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar, 23.Klungland A. Hoss M. Gunz D. Constantinou A. Clarkson S.G. Doetsch P.W. Bolton P.H. Wood R.D. Lindahl T. Mol. Cell. 1999; 3: 1-20Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (252) Google Scholar). However, the DNA repair synthesis at 8-OH-dG was less efficient than that at regular AP sites (7.Fortini P. Parlanti E. Sidorkina O.M. Laval J. Dogliotti E. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 15230-15236Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar). Therefore, it has been proposed that the first three processes from base release to excision of 3′-AP sites may be rate-limiting steps. Our data suggest that 3′-phosphoesterase activity to repair 3′-AP sites is not rate-limiting in base excision repair. Based on these results, the excision of modified bases may be one of the rate-determining processes in the 8-OH-dG base excision repair pathway. Furthermore, in human cultured cells, oxidative stress induced AP endonuclease and rendered cells resistant to oxidative stress (26.Ramana C.V. Boldogh I. Izumi T. Mitra S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 5061-5066Crossref PubMed Scopus (375) Google Scholar). These results also raised the possibility that 3′-AP sites generated by bifunctional DNA glycosylases may induce AP endonuclease. In addition to 3′-AP sites, ROS also induced other 3′-phosphate lesions, including 3′-phosphoglycolate. These 3′-blocked termini might be one of the reasons for AP endonuclease induction in cells under oxidative stress conditions. Although the Fenton reaction directly induced a significant number of intact AP sites in the in vitro system, the number of intact AP sites was not increased in cells exposed to H2O2. Both regular AP sites and C-4′-oxidized AP sites without strand breaks directly induced by bleomycin are repaired by an interaction of AP endonuclease and β-polin vitro using oligonucleotides (20.Xu Y.-j. Kim E.Y. Demple B. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 28837-28844Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar, 27.Bennett R.A. Wilson III, D.M. Wong D. Demple B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 7166-7169Crossref PubMed Scopus (325) Google Scholar). Based on these data and our experiments, the regular and oxidized aldehydic AP sites with no cleavage on either side induced by ROS appear to be efficiently repaired in cells through a base excision repair pathway. A high concentration of TEMPO almost completely protected the formation of AP sites, End III-sensitive sites, and 8-OH-dG induced by a high level of oxidative stress. Furthermore, DNA extracted from fresh calf thymus also showed very low amounts of 8-OH-dG (<1 lesion/107 nucleotides). In contrast, the range of steady-state levels of 8-OH-dG measured by HPLC/electrochemical detection has varied from 4 to 800 lesions/107 nucleotides in mammalian cells and tissues (28.Helbock H.L. Beckman K.B. Shigenaga M.K. Walter P.B. Woodall A.A. Yeo H.C. Ames B.N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 288-293Crossref PubMed Scopus (612) Google Scholar). There are many factors that artifactually induce oxidative DNA lesions during DNA extraction (24.Cadet J. Delatour T. Douki T. Gasparutto D. Pouget J.-P. Ravanat J.-L. Sauvarigo S. Mutat. Res. 1999; 424: 9-21Crossref PubMed Scopus (515) Google Scholar). The trapping of free radicals by TEMPO appears to be quite efficient for preventing artifactual DNA damage from oxidative stress. Therefore, the current DNA extraction method using a high concentration of TEMPO minimizes the artifactual induction of oxidative lesions during DNA extraction. In the present experiment, 10 mmH2O2 increased the number of 8-OH-dGs by a factor of >30 over the control. These data indicate that reduction of artifactual oxidative DNA lesions will also allow us to more accurately determine dose-response relationships as well as the repair kinetics of these lesions after oxidative stress. Further studies are needed to understand the biological consequences of 5′-AP sites persisting in cells under normal physiological conditions as well as after oxidative stress. Although H2O2 killed HeLa cells within 24 h at 20 mm, a limited number of cells survived after exposure to 10 mm H2O2 and started growing within 1–2 days (data not shown). These results suggest that 5′-oxidized AP sites are repairable by cellular DNA repair pathways. Recently, Jacksonet al. (25.Jackson A.L. Chen R. Loeb L.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 12468-12473Crossref PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar) demonstrated that oxidative stress, but not UV radiation or methylating agent, induces frameshift mutations in microsatellite DNA. They proposed that a common lesion such as a strand break is more likely to contribute to genomic instability than the alteration of a specific nucleotide. It is possible that 5′-oxidized AP sites might be involved in the frameshift mutation in microsatellite DNA. To date, it has generally been believed that AP sites are repaired very efficiently in genomic DNA; however, the high steady-state level of 5′-nicked AP sites as well as persistent 5′-cleaved AP sites after oxidative stress suggest that some fraction of AP sites may not be efficiently repaired by the mammalian excision repair pathway. We thank Drs. S. H. Wilson, Y. W. Kow, and K. McDorman for providing human β-pol, E. coliEnd III, and fresh calf thymus, respectively.

We investigated the profound involvement of chymase, an alternative angiotensin II-generating enzyme, in angiogenesis using a hamster sponge implant model. In vivotransfection of human pro-chymase cDNA or a direct injection of purified chymase into the sponges implanted resulted in marked increment of hemoglobin contents in the sponge granuloma tissues, demonstrating that chymase has an ability to elicit angiogenesis and is a potent angiogenic factor. Daily injection of basic fibroblast growth factor into the sponges implanted also induced angiogenesis, which was suppressed by the treatment with chymostatin, an inhibitor of chymase, or TCV-116, an antagonist of angiotensin II (Ang II) type 1 receptor. Expression of chymase mRNA and production of Ang II in the granuloma tissues were enhanced by the stimulation with basic fibroblast growth factor. Chymase activity in the sponge granulomas increased in parallel with the rise in hemoglobin contents, and mast cells observed in the granuloma tissues were positively stained with anti-chymase antibody. Exogenous administration not only of Ang II but of angiotensin I (Ang I) directly into the sponges could enhance angiogenesis. Chymostatin inhibited the angiogenesis induced by Ang I but not Ang II, suggesting the presence of a chymase-like Ang II-generating activity in the sponge granulomas. Our results may suggest a potential ability of chymase to promote angiogenesis through the local chymase-dependent and angiotensin-converting enzyme-dependent Ang II generating system in pathophysiological angiogenesis. Our results may suggest a potential ability of chymase to promote angiogenesis through the local chymase-dependent and angiotensin-converting enzyme-dependent Ang II generating system in pathophysiological angiogenesis. basic fibroblast growth factor angiotensin I angiotensin II angiotensin-converting enzyme reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction phosphate-buffered saline lima bean trypsin inhibitor soybean trypsin inhibitor N-CBZ-l-phenylalanine chloromethyl ketone Angiogenesis is a process involved in many physiological events including embryonic development, placental implantation, and wound repair. It also occurs under certain pathological conditions such as cancer, diabetic retinopathy, and rheumatoid arthritis, where angiogenesis has responsible for the progression of such diseases (1.Folkman J. N. Engl. J. Med. 1971; 285: 1182-1186Crossref PubMed Scopus (220) Google Scholar, 2.Michaelson I.C. Trans. Ophthalmol. UK. 1948; 68: 137-180Google Scholar, 3.Wise G.N. Trans. Am. Ophthalmol. Soc. 1956; 54: 729-826PubMed Google Scholar, 4.Peacock D.J. Banquerigo M.L. Brahn E. J. Exp. Med. 1992; 175: 1135-1138Crossref PubMed Scopus (183) Google Scholar, 5.Colville-Nash P.R. Scott D.L. Annu. Rheum. Dis. 1992; 51: 919-925Crossref PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar). Complex and diverse processes are implicated in angiogenesis, in that a variety of cells and biologically active substances are involved in the construction of new blood vessels. Numerous factors including growth factors such as basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF),1 vascular endothelial cell growth factor, transforming growth factor-β, or epidermal growth factor have been shown to regulate neovascularization both positively and negatively. Angiotensin II (Ang II) is one of important regulators of blood pressure and blood flow by modifying the vascular tone. It promotes angiogenesis by stimulating proliferation and migration of the smooth muscle cells in vitro (6.Bell L. Madri J.A. Am. J. Pathol. 1990; 137: 7-12PubMed Google Scholar, 7.Paquet J.L. Baudouin-Legros M. Brunelle G. Meyer P. J. Hypertens. 1990; 8: 565-572Crossref PubMed Scopus (191) Google Scholar, 8.Lyall F. Morton J.J. Lever A.F. Cragoe E.J. J. Hypertens. 1988; 6 (Suppl. 4): S438-S441Crossref Scopus (55) Google Scholar, 9.Aceto J.F. Baker K.M. Am. J. Physiol. 1990; 258: H806-H813PubMed Google Scholar). It also enhances neovascularization in in vivo angiogenesis models (10.Hu D.-E. Hiley C.R. Fan T.-P.D. Br. J. Pharmacol. 1996; 117: 545-551Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 11.Fernandez L.A. Twickler J. Mead A. J. Lab. Clin. Med. 1985; 105: 141-145PubMed Google Scholar, 12.Le Noble F.A.C. Hekking J.W.M. Van Straaten H.W.M. Slaaf D.W. Boudier H.A.J.S. Eur. J. Pharmacol. 1991; 195: 305-306Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar). However, a pathway for local generation of Ang II has not been clarified in detail. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) has been characterized to be an unique enzyme to convert Ang I to Ang II under the physiological conditions. Furthermore, the ACE-dependent conversion has been believed to be predominant in the production of Ang II. Recently, an alternative pathway for generating Ang II, i.e. the chymase-dependent angiotensin II-generating system, has been identified (13.Reilly C.F. Tewksbury D.A. Schechter N.M. Travis J. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 8619-8622Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Chymase is a chymotrypsin-like serine protease originally found as a mast cell protease (14.Lagunoff D. Benditt E.P. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1963; 103: 185-198Crossref PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar). Active chymase is stored in the secretary granules of mast cells and is released upon the degranulation, suggesting that it may be involved in various inflammatory and immunological disorders. However, the specific substrates for chymase and its physiological and pathophysiological roles are not well known. Although Ang I has reported to serve as a favorite substrate for chymase, there is a marked species difference in the Ang II forming activity (15.Okunishi H. Oka Y. Shiota N. Kawamoto T. Song K. Miyazaki M. Jpn. J. Pharmacol. 1993; 62: 207-210Crossref PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar, 16.Okunishi H. Miyazaki M. Toda N. J. Hypertens. 1984; 2: 277-284Crossref PubMed Scopus (186) Google Scholar, 17.Okunishi H. Miyazaki M. Okamura T. Toda N. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1987; 149: 1186-1192Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar, 18.Okamura T. Okunishi H. Ayajiki K. Toda N. J. Cardiovasc. Pharmacol. 1990; 15: 353-359Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar, 19.Takai S. Shiota N. Yamamoto D. Okunishi H. Miyazaki M. Life Sci. 1996; 58: 591-597Crossref PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar). In humans, dogs, monkeys, or hamsters, chymase produces Ang II from Ang I, whereas it cleaves Ang I into inactive fragments in rabbits, rats, or mice. Therefore the former experimental animals, in which endogenous conversion of Ang I to Ang II is anticipated, but not the latter should be used for elucidation of the biological functions of chymase in humans. Taken together these information, we focused on a role of chymase in angiogenesis by using the in vivo hamster model. Thus results from the present study raised the possibility that chymase could play a potent role in angiogenesis via a conversion of Ang I endogenously and a possible suppression of angiogenesis by the inhibitior of chymase. All chemicals were reagent grade. Angiotensin I, angiotensin II, chymostatin, lima bean trypsin inhibitor (LBTI), soybean trypsin inhibitor (SBTI),N-CBZ-l-phenylalanine chloromethyl ketone (ZPCK), and o-phthaldialdehyde were purchased from Sigma. Diisopropyl fluorophosphate, Hemoglobin B-test®, and peroxidase-labeled goat anti-rabbit IgG were purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Industries (Osaka, Japan). Dipyridyl was purchased from KANTO Chemicals (Tokyo, Japan). Recombinant human bFGF was purchased from Seikagaku Corporation (Tokyo, Japan). TCV-116, an Ang II receptor antagonist, was a kind gift from Takeda Chemical Industries (Osaka, Japan). Anti-hamster chymase antibody was raised against rabbit by immunizing IIGGTECKPHSRPYMAYLEIV, a fragment of hamster chymase (Iwaki Glass, Chiba, Japan). LipofectAMINE was purchased from Life Technologies, Inc. pCXN2, an expression plasmid, was kindly provided by Dr. Junichi Miyazaki (University of Tokushima). Sephadex G-100 and Hitrap heparin column were purchased from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech. Messenger RNA capture kit was purchased from Roche Molecular Biochemicals. Ang II concentration was determined by using an enzyme immunoassay kit (Peninsula Laboratories, Belmont, CA). Circular sponge discs (5-mm-thick, 1.3 cm in diameter, and weighing 14.2 ± 0.1 mg) were prepared from a sheet of polyurethane foam using a wad pouch. The discs were soaked in 70% ethanol overnight and then sterilized with an autoclave. These sponge discs were implanted under aseptic conditions in the subcutaneous air pouch in the dorsum of each male Syrian hamster (6 weeks old) purchased from SLC (Shizuoka, Japan), under light anesthesia with ether. At the end of the experimental period, the animal was sacrificed, and the granuloma tissues were excised immediately, together with the enclosed sponge implants. The obtained tissues were divided into two halves, one for measuring the hemoglobin contents and the other for measuring chymase activity. Male Harlan Sprague-Dawley rats (7 weeks old) purchased from SLC were also used in the same manner. We have previously shown that the hemoglobin contents in the sponge implants and the surrounding granuloma tissue correlated with the degree of angiogenesis (20.Majima M. Isono M. Ikeda Y. Hayashi I. Hatanaka K. Harada Y. Katsumata O. Yamashina S. Katori M. Yamamoto S. Jpn. J. Pharmacol. 1997; 75: 105-114Crossref PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar). Therefore, we measured the hemoglobin contents of the implant samples according to the method of Majima et al. (20.Majima M. Isono M. Ikeda Y. Hayashi I. Hatanaka K. Harada Y. Katsumata O. Yamashina S. Katori M. Yamamoto S. Jpn. J. Pharmacol. 1997; 75: 105-114Crossref PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar) as a parameter for angiogenesis. Briefly, the sample granuloma tissues were weighed and homogenized with a Polytrone homogenizer (Kinematica Inc., Cincinnati, OH) in distilled water (4 ml/g of wet weight). The hemoglobin concentration in the supernatant after centrifugation at 5,000 × g was determined by a hemoglobin assay kit (Hemoglobin B-test, Wako). Hamster chymase was purified from cheek pouches as described by Takai et al. (19.Takai S. Shiota N. Yamamoto D. Okunishi H. Miyazaki M. Life Sci. 1996; 58: 591-597Crossref PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar). Briefly, hamster cheek pouches were minced and homogenized in 10 volumes (w/v) of 20 mm sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.4). After centrifugation at 20,000 × g for 30 min at 4 °C, the pellet was resuspended and extracted for 24 h at 4 °C in five volumes (w/v) of 10 mm sodium phosphate buffer containing 2 m KCl and 0.1% Nonidet P-40. The extracts were centrifuged at 20,000 × g for 30 min, and the supernatant was applied to a Sephadex G-100 column (2.6 × 100 cm), which was equilibrated with 10 mm sodium phosphate buffer containing 2 m KCl. Active fractions with Ang II forming activity were collected and concentrated and then applied to a heparin affinity column with 5 ml of the gel volume (Hitrap, Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). Proteins were eluted with a linear gradient (0–100%) of 20 mm Tris buffer (pH 8.0) containing 1.8m KCl and 0.1% Triton X-100. Fractions containing chymase activity were collected and dialyzed overnight at 4 °C against sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.8) containing 0.7 m NaCl. The dialysate was stored at −80 °C. Just prior to the experiments, the chymase fraction was diluted with 10 mm phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) to reduce sodium concentration to the physiological range. The purified protein showed a single band on SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis with a silver staining The cDNA for human pro-chymase was cloned from premade cDNA library prepared from human adult normal heart (Invitrogen, CA) using PCR as described by Urata et al. (21.Urata H. Kinoshita A. Perez D.M. Misono K.S. Bumpus F.M. Graham R.M. Husain A. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 17173-17179Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The entire PCR product was subcloned into pBS II KS (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA). The cloned cDNA was sequenced and confirmed to contain a single ATG codon at the 5′ end followed by an entire open reading frame by 741 base pairs encoding 247 amino acids. The cDNA fragment was excised from EcoRI site of the pBS II KS and ligated into EcoRI site of pCXN2 to construct the expression plasmid. Plasmid DNA was purified by using a Qiagen Plasmid Kit (Qiagen GmbH, Hilden, Germany) after transformation in Escherichia coli (DH5α). In vivotransfection of cDNA was carried out using lipofection method. Briefly, 80 μg of the human pro-chymase expression plasmid (pHCM) was mixed with 80 μl of LipofectAMINE and the mixture was left for 40 min at room temperature to form liposome complex. The liposome-cDNA mixture was injected into the subcutaneous tissue near the sponges implanted into the back of hamsters. Gene transfection was performed twice at days 1 and 5 of the experiment, and assessment of angiogenesis was performed on the 7th day after implantation. pCXN2vector alone was used for mock transfection in the same manner. Poly(A)+RNA was isolated from the sponge granulomas by using mRNA Capture Kit (Roche Molecular Biochemicals). First-stranded cDNA was synthesized by reverse transcription reaction using Titan one-tube RT-PCR system (Roche Molecular Biochemicals) according to the manufacturer's instructions. As PCR primers, 5′-aacttccaacgtccctc-3′ (sense) and 5′-gattgtggtcaaagtctc-3′ (antisense) for human prochymase cDNA, 5′-gggttcctcataacgccag-3′ (sense) and 5′-aattgcttgcctttatgactatattaattc-3′ (antisense) for hamster chymase cDNA, or 5′-ccaaggccaaccgcgagaagatgac-3′ (sense) and 5′-agggtacatggtggtgccgccagac-3′ (antisense) for hamster β-actin cDNA were used for the amplifications. The reaction was allowed to process for 20 cycles. Each cycle consists of 30 s at 94 °C for denature, 30 s at 55 °C for annealing, and 60 s 72 °C for extension, followed by a 10-min extension at 72 °C. Aliquots of the reaction mixture were separated on 2% agarose gel. Human prochymase, hamster chymase, and hamster β-actin cDNAs were detected as products of 411, 589, and 580 base pairs, respectively. To measure chymase activity, each sample was homogenized with a Polytrone homogenizer in 10 mm sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) containing 2m KCl and 0.1% Nonidet P-40. After the extraction for 1 h with shaking followed by centrifugation at 20,000 ×g for 1 h, chymase activity in the supernatant was determined according to the method of Okunishi et al. (17.Okunishi H. Miyazaki M. Okamura T. Toda N. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1987; 149: 1186-1192Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar). Briefly, aliquots of the tissue extract were incubated for 1 h at 37 °C with 770 μm of Ang I in 48.5 mmborax-borate buffer (pH 8.5) containing 8 mm dipyridyl, 760 μm diisopropyl phosphorofluoridate, and 5 mmEDTA as inhibitors of ACE and angiotensinases. Reactions were terminated by the addition of 15% cold trichloroacetic acid (which gives 9% of the final concentration), followed by centrifugation at 10,000 × g for 5 min. The concentration of His-Leu, an enzymatic cleavage product, in the supernatant was determined from fluorescent intensity as follows. 10% of o-phthaldialdehyde was added to the supernatant in an alkaline condition (pH 12.0) followed by the addition of 6 n HCl (brought to pH 3) to stabilize. The fluorescence in the solution was measured at 340 nm of excitation and at 455 nm of emission. At day 7, a polyethylene cannula was inserted into a carotid artery of each hamster, and the hamsters were perfused with saline to remove blood in the granuloma tissues under anesthesia with pentobarbital sodium (25 mg/kg intraperitoneal). The sponge granulomas were rapidly frozen with liquid nitrogen immediately after the excision. The frozen samples were minced into small pieces, followed by an overnight incubation in ice-cold ethanol to extract Ang II. After the incubation, samples were centrifugated, and the supernatant was evaporated to remove ethanol. The extracts were then treated with diethylether for 1 h with shaking, and the supernatant was evaporated. Finally, the pellets were dissolved with PBS, and the concentrations of Ang II were determined by using a high sensitivity enzyme immunoassay. For histological studies, the excised sample sponges were fixed in 10% (w/v) formalin solution at 4 °C and were embedded in paraffin wax. Thin sections (5 μm) were prepared and stained with the method of van Gieson (22.Pearse A.G.E. Histochemistry. 2. Churchill Livingston, London1985Google Scholar) or acidified toluidine blue. For immunohistochemistry, sample sponges were frozen with liquid nitrogen immediately after the excision. After treatment with ethanol and subsequent blocking, sections were incubated with rabbit anti-hamster chymase IgG. They were then washed three times with PBS, incubated with peroxidase-labeled goat anti-rabbit IgG, and colored by 3,3′-diaminobenzidine tetrahydrochloride solution. Counterstaining was performed with hematoxylin. All drugs, with the exception of TCV-116, were administered daily into the sponges for 7 days. TCV-116 was suspended in 0.5% carboxymethylcellulose and was administered orally once a day. Chymostatin was solubilized with dimethyl sulfoxide and then diluted with PBS (the final concentration of dimethyl sulfoxide was 0.05%). All data were expressed as the means ± S.E. Differences between groups were examined for statistical significance using the Student's t test. Ap value less than 0.05 denoted the presence of a statistically significant difference. Whether chymase exert to induce angiogenesis in vivo was examined by using the hamster sponge implant model. Angiogenesis was evaluated as contents of hemoglobin in the sponge granulomas. Direct administration of 14 μg/site/day of hamster chymase, which was purified from the cheek pouches, into the sponge implant elicited the angiogenesis. As shown in Fig. 1 A, a significant increase of hemoglobin contents was observed in the sponges of chymase-injected group from day 2 to day 7 of the experiments, when compared with vehicle-injected controls. The increment in hemoglobin contents was accelerated from day 5 to day 7. To ascertain that this chymase-induced angiogenesis was mediated by generation of Ang II, the effect of angiotensin type I receptor antagonist, TCV-116, was tested. Oral administration of TCV-116 (5 mg/kg/day) for 7 days significantly inhibited the hemoglobin contents by approximately 50% (Fig.1 B). To confirm that chymase is angiogenic, the transiently expression plasmid for human pro-chymase cDNA was transfected twice into the sponges at days 1 and 5 by lipofection method. A significant level of angiogenesis was induced in the sponges at day 7 (Fig.2 A), which were transfected with the expression plasmid for pro-chymase cDNA, as compared with the sponges transfected with pCXN2 vector plasmid alone (Fig. 2 B). Apparent expression of human chymase mRNA in sponge granulomas transfected with pHCM was observed by RT-PCR. Primers used for PCR were specific for human chymase cDNA, not for hamsters (Fig. 2 C). No product was amplified in the sponges transfected with pCXN2 vector alone. The hemoglobin contents in the sponge granulomas were significantly higher in pHCM-transfected hamsters than those in hamsters transfected with pCXN2 or in vehicle-injected controls (Fig. 2 C). Progressive neovascularization was also assessed by microscopic histological evaluation. In the sponge granulomas expressing human chymase cDNA, the density of newly formed microvessels was much higher than in those transfected with pCXN2 (data not shown). To clarify the involvement of endogenous chymase in angiogenesis, bFGF, which is one of potent angiogenic factors, was used to induce angiogenesis in the sponge implants model. As shown in Fig.3 A, daily administrations of 0.3 μg/site of bFGF caused a marked increase in hemoglobin contents from day 2. The hemoglobin content at day 11 increased to 7.4 ± 0.90 mg/g of tissue. In control hamsters treated with saline, an increment of hemoglobin contents was slowly and gradually occurred. The stimulatory effect of bFGF on the angiogenesis was dose-dependent (Fig. 3 B). Expression of chymase mRNA was detectable in the sponge granuloma stimulated with bFGF but not that stimulated with saline (Fig.4). Functionally active chymase in sponge granuloma tissues when stimulated with bFGF (0.3 μg/site/day) was measured, and a correlation of the activity with the development of angiogenesis was examined. Chymase activity was estimated as measurable angiotensin converting activity, which is chymostatin-sensitive and captopril-insensitive, in the sponge granuloma tissue. There was a significant correlation (p < 0.001, by Fisher's Z-transformation) between chymase activities and hemoglobin contents in the granuloma tissues (Fig. 3 C). Whether intrinsic Ang II was produced in the sponge granulomas was examined. Extracts from granuloma tissues were subjected to enzyme immunoassay for Ang II. A tremendous increment of Ang II was measured in the granuloma stimulated with bFGF (Fig.5). This increase was significantly inhibited by the treatment with a chymase inhibitor, chymostatin. To investigate the involvement of chymase in bFGF-induced angiogenesis in hamsters, several chymase inhibitors were used. Chymostatin inhibited the bFGF-induced angiogenesis in a dose-dependent manner when it was applied 1 h prior to the injection of bFGF into the sponges (Fig. 6). A significant inhibition was observed at a dose exceeding 1 nmol/site/day. The maximum inhibition was 69% at 10 nmol/site/day. The inhibitory effect of chymostatin at doses more than 10 nmol/site could not be examined because of insolubility of the compound. Administrations of other chymase inhibitors, LBTI, SBTI, and ZPCK (19.Takai S. Shiota N. Yamamoto D. Okunishi H. Miyazaki M. Life Sci. 1996; 58: 591-597Crossref PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar, 23.Johnson L.A. Moon K.E. Eisenberg M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1988; 953: 269-279Crossref PubMed Scopus (12) Google Scholar), also resulted in a significant reduction of hemoglobin contents in the sponge implants (Fig. 6 A). Administration of chymostatin alone without bFGF did not show any inhibitory or stimulatory effect (data not shown). Previous studies have shown that Ang II is produced in hamsters from Ang I by the alternative chymase-dependent pathway as well as the conventional ACE-dependent pathway, which is quite similar in humans (19.Takai S. Shiota N. Yamamoto D. Okunishi H. Miyazaki M. Life Sci. 1996; 58: 591-597Crossref PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar). Therefore, we then investigated the contribution of endogenous Ang II in bFGF-induced angiogenesis using hamsters. Oral administration of TCV-116 suppressed the angiogenesis in a dose-dependent manner (Fig. 6 B). The maximum inhibition (67%) occurred at 5 mg/kg/day, although further inhibition was not obtained even at higher doses. On the other hand, captopril, an inhibitor of ACE, also showed the suppression (Fig. 6 A). The inhibitory effect of captopril was less than that of chymostatin. As shown in Fig. 6 B, the combined use of chymostatin and TCV-116 at 10 nmol/site/day and 5 mg/kg/day, respectively (representing the dose at which each agent induced maximum inhibition when used alone), resulted in much more potent inhibition of the bFGF-induced angiogenesis. In rat, whereas captopril exhibited a significant inhibition, chymostatin did not (Fig. 6 C). To identify the presence and the localization of chymase in the implanted sponge granulomas of hamsters, immunohistochemical studies were carried out. As shown in Fig.7 A, the granuloma tissue, which consisted mainly of the fibrous matrix and numerous fibroblast-like cells, encapsulated the sponge implant, and the pores of the sponge were also infiltrated with the fibrous stroma. Macrophage-like cells were also observed in granulomas and within the stroma. Newly formed microvessels (indicated by arrows in Fig. 7 A) were often seen in the granulomas, especially at the periphery. Sections stained with toluidine blue showed the presence of mast cells mainly around newly formed microvessels (Fig.7 B). Almost all mast cells in the sections were positively stained with anti-hamster chymase antibody (Fig. 7 C). Pathol. 1990; 137: 7-12PubMed Google Scholar, 7.Paquet J.L. Baudouin-Legros M. Brunelle G. Meyer P. J. Hypertens. 1990; 8: 565-572Crossref PubMed Scopus (191) Google Scholar, 8.Lyall F. Morton J.J. Lever A.F. Cragoe E.J. J. Hypertens. 1988; 6 (Suppl. 4): S438-S441Crossref Scopus (55) Google Scholar, 9.Aceto J.F. Baker K.M. Am. J. Physiol. 1990; 258: H806-H813PubMed Google Scholar). Recent studies have shown that exogenously administered Ang II also stimulates angiogenesis in vivo (10.Hu D.-E. Hiley C.R. Fan T.-P.D. Br. J. Pharmacol. 1996; 117: 545-551Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 11.Fernandez L.A. Twickler J. Mead A. J. Lab. Clin. Med. 1985; 105: 141-145PubMed Google Scholar, 12.Le Noble F.A.C. Hekking J.W.M. Van Straaten H.W.M. Slaaf D.W. Boudier H.A.J.S. Eur. J. Pharmacol. 1991; 195: 305-306Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar). In the following experiments, to evaluate the angiogenic activity of Ang I, which is a biologically inactive precursor of Ang II, the direct effect of Ang I on the induction of angiogenesis was compared with that of Ang II in our model. Daily administrations of Ang II for 7 days increased the hemoglobin contents in a dose-dependent manner (Fig.8 A). The maximum response (7.9 ± 0.79 mg/g of wet tissue) was obtained at a dose of 2 μg/site/day, although the hemoglobin content slightly decreased at higher doses (5.8 ± 0.78 mg/g of wet tissue at 5 μg/site/day). Administration of Ang I into the sponges also could induce the angiogenesis. The dose dependence of the response was almost similar to that of Ang II. Furthermore the extent of the maximum response by Ang I (6.9 ± 1.1 mg/g of wet tissue), obtained at 2 μg/site/day, was almost the same as that observed in Ang II-induced angiogenesis (Fig.8 A). The time course of hemoglobin increment when stimulated with Ang I was quite similar to that when stimulated with Ang II. This considerable angiogenic activity of Ang I was significantly reduced by the treatment with chymase inhibitors, chymostatin, SBTI, LBTI, or ZPCK (Fig. 9). The maximal inhibition was more than 60% by daily injections of chymostatin at a dose of 1 nmol/day. Those inhibitors showed no effects on the angiogenesis induced by Ang II (data not shown). Recently, the role of Ang II as a growth factor has gained much interest (6.Bell L. Madri J.A. Am. J. Pathol. 1990; 137: 7-12PubMed Google Scholar, 7.Paquet J.L. Baudouin-Legros M. Brunelle G. Meyer P. J. H

We have identified a mouse PDZ protein that interacts with the activin type IIA receptor (ActRIIA), which we named activin receptor-interacting protein 1 (ARIP1). By using yeast two-hybrid screening, we isolated a cDNA clone of ARIP1 from a mouse brain cDNA library. We detected two forms of ARIP1, ARIP1-long and ARIP1-short, which may be produced by alternative splicing. ARIP1-long had one guanylate kinase domain in the NH2-terminal region, followed by two WW domains and five PDZ domains (PDZ1–5). ARIP1-short had a deletion in the NH2-terminal region and lacked the guanylate kinase domain. Both forms interacted with ActRIIA through PDZ5. The COOH-terminal residues of ActRIIA (ESSL) agree with a PDZ-binding consensus motif, and ARIP1 recognized the consensus sequence. ARIP1 interacts specifically with ActRIIA among the receptors for the transforming growth factor β family. Interestingly, ARIP1 also interacted with Smad3, which is an activin/transforming growth factor β intracellular signaling molecule. The mRNA of ARIP1 was more abundant in the brain than in other tissues. Overexpression of ARIP1 controls activin-induced and Smad3-induced transcription in activin-responsive cell lines. These findings suggest that ARIP1 has a significant role in assembling activin signaling molecules at specific subcellular sites and in regulating signal transduction in neuronal cells. We have identified a mouse PDZ protein that interacts with the activin type IIA receptor (ActRIIA), which we named activin receptor-interacting protein 1 (ARIP1). By using yeast two-hybrid screening, we isolated a cDNA clone of ARIP1 from a mouse brain cDNA library. We detected two forms of ARIP1, ARIP1-long and ARIP1-short, which may be produced by alternative splicing. ARIP1-long had one guanylate kinase domain in the NH2-terminal region, followed by two WW domains and five PDZ domains (PDZ1–5). ARIP1-short had a deletion in the NH2-terminal region and lacked the guanylate kinase domain. Both forms interacted with ActRIIA through PDZ5. The COOH-terminal residues of ActRIIA (ESSL) agree with a PDZ-binding consensus motif, and ARIP1 recognized the consensus sequence. ARIP1 interacts specifically with ActRIIA among the receptors for the transforming growth factor β family. Interestingly, ARIP1 also interacted with Smad3, which is an activin/transforming growth factor β intracellular signaling molecule. The mRNA of ARIP1 was more abundant in the brain than in other tissues. Overexpression of ARIP1 controls activin-induced and Smad3-induced transcription in activin-responsive cell lines. These findings suggest that ARIP1 has a significant role in assembling activin signaling molecules at specific subcellular sites and in regulating signal transduction in neuronal cells. transforming growth factor-β activin type IIA receptor activin receptor-interacting protein 1 Chinese hamster ovary cytomegalovirus β-galactosidase guanylate kinase N-methyl-d-aspartate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis polymerase chain reaction Activin is a multifunctional growth and differentiation factor that belongs to the transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β)1 superfamily. Activin has numerous biological activities: regulation of secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone from pituitary cells (1.Vale W. Rivier J. Vaughan J. McClintock R. Corrigan A. Woo W. Karr D. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1987; 142: 1095-1103Crossref PubMed Scopus (381) Google Scholar), and mesoderm induction inXenopus embryos (4.Asashima M. Nakano H. Shimada K. Kinoshita K. Ishii K. Shibai H. Ueno N. Roux's Arch. Dev. Biol. 1990; 198: 330-335Crossref Scopus (333) Google Scholar). Activin has also been reported to act on neural cells. Activin is a survival factor for neural cells derived from rat brain (5.Schubert D. Kimura H. LaCorbiere M. Vaughan J. Karr D. Fischer W.H. Nature. 1990; 344: 868-870Crossref PubMed Scopus (273) Google Scholar), regulates neuronal development in the avian iris and ciliary body (6.Link B.A. Nishi R. Dev. A. 1994; 91: 43-47Crossref PubMed Scopus (148) Google Scholar). Activin signals through two types of membrane-bound receptor complexes on the target cells (8.Tsuchida K. Vaughan J.M. Wiater E. Gaddy-Kurten D. Vale W.W. Endocrinology. 1995; 136: 5493-5503Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar, 9.Willis S.A. Zimmerman C.M. Li L.I. Mathews L.S. Mol. Endocrinol. 1996; 10: 367-379Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar, 10.Attisano L. Wrana J.L. Montalvo E. Massagué J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 1066-1073Crossref PubMed Scopus (285) Google Scholar). Two types of activin receptor have been identified, type I and type II, both of which belong to the family of serine/threonine kinase receptors. Interaction between the type I and type II receptors is necessary for activin-induced signal transduction. Activin binds directly to the type II receptor, which then recruits the type I receptor to the complex and phosphorylates it, resulting in the activation of the type I receptor and in the downstream propagation of the signal (11.Mathews L.S. Endocr. Rev. 1994; 15: 310-325Crossref PubMed Scopus (272) Google Scholar). There are two subtypes of the type II activin receptor, types IIA (ActRIIA) and IIB (ActRIIB), which are encoded by individual genes. In addition, two splice variants of ActRIIA including ActRIIA-N (12.Mathews L.S. Vale W.W. Cell. 1991; 65: 973-982Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (680) Google Scholar, 13.Shoji H. Nakamura T. van den Eijnden-van Raaij A.J. Sugino H. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1998; 246: 320-324Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar) and five splice variants of ActRIIB have been reported (14.Attisano L. Wrana J.L. Cheifetz S. Massagué J. Cell. 1992; 68: 97-108Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (458) Google Scholar, 15.Ethier J.F. Lussier J.G. Silversides D.W. Endocrinology. 1997; 138: 2425-2434Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). We have previously shown that ActRIIA-N is expressed specifically in neural tissues (13.Shoji H. Nakamura T. van den Eijnden-van Raaij A.J. Sugino H. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1998; 246: 320-324Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). Although our understanding of activin/TGF-β signaling pathways has progressed during past few years (16.Massagué J. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1998; 67: 753-791Crossref PubMed Scopus (3983) Google Scholar), the significance of the various type II activin receptors is not known. Recent investigations have suggested that signal transduction via transmembrane receptors is regulated by PDZ domain-containing molecules that interact with the receptors. Many PDZ domain-containing proteins have a role in assembling receptors and signaling molecules in the cell membrane and in submembranous regions. To determine the specific functions of the activin type IIA receptors in activin signal transduction, we searched for cytoplasmic proteins that interact with these receptors. We identified a novel cytoplasmic protein, which we named activin receptor-interacting protein 1 (ARIP1), that is abundant in the brain. ARIP1 had multiple protein-protein interaction domains, including two WW domains and five PDZ domains, and it interacted with Smad3 as well as with ActRIIA and ActRIIA-N. Thus, ARIP1 is a scaffolding protein that unites activin receptors with an intracellular signaling molecule (Smad) and thereby regulates activin-mediated signaling in neuronal cells. Yeast two-hybrid screening was performed using a commercially available system (Matchmaker Two-Hybrid System 2;CLONTECH) according to the manufacturer's protocol. Approximately 4 × 106 clones of a mouse brain cDNA library (CLONTECH) were screened using a bait construct, pAS-ActRIIA-N, that contained the nucleotide sequences for the entire cytoplasmic region of mouse ActRIIA-N fused to a GAL4 DNA-binding domain. To obtain a full-length clone for ARIP1, a mouse brain cDNA library in the λZAPII vector (STRATAGENE) was screened using the insert of #YN3 as the probe. One clone encoding the full-length of the ARIP1-short sequence was identified. A cDNA encoding ARIP1-long was obtained by joining the ARIP1-short cDNA and the PCR-derived NH2-terminal sequence. Reverse transcription-PCR was performed using a sense primer synthesized according to the rat S-SCAM sequence (nucleotides 30–49, 5′-agagaaaggcaaagtctgcc-3′; Ref. 20.Hirao K. Hata Y. Ide N. Takeuchi M. Irie M. Yao I. Deguchi M. Toyoda A. Sudhof T.C. Takai Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 21105-21110Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (255) Google Scholar) and an antisense primer based on the mouse ARIP1-short sequence (nucleotides 1117–1140, 5′-gtagctcccggaagtatctggtct-3′). The amplified products were cloned into pUC19, sequenced, and ligated to the ARIP1-short cDNA. DNA constructs for yeast two-hybrid screening were made using the plasmid pAS2–1 to express the fusion protein with the GAL4 DNA-binding domain, and the plasmid pACT2 was used to express the fusion protein with the GAL4 activation domain. pAS-ActRIIA and pAS-ActRIIA-N were made by introducing nucleotides 554–1995 of mouse ActRIIA (12.Mathews L.S. Vale W.W. Cell. 1991; 65: 973-982Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (680) Google Scholar) or nucleotides 554–2019 of ActRIIA-N (13.Shoji H. Nakamura T. van den Eijnden-van Raaij A.J. Sugino H. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1998; 246: 320-324Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar) into pAS2–1. An insert fragment of pACT2-ARIP1-long was made by ligating a PCR-amplified fragment that contained the translational start methionine codon to a KpnI/EcoRV fragment (nucleotides 1071–4446) of the ARIP1-short cDNA. pACT2-ARIP1-short was made by introducing nucleotides 1187–4446 of pBS-ARIP1-short into pACT2. A series of deletion mutants was made by combining PCR-generated fragments and fragments prepared from pBS-ARIP1-short. pAS-ΔGuk-PDZ2 contained nucleotides 2830–4446, pAS-ΔGuk-PDZ4 contained nucleotides 3826–4446, pAS-ΔPDZ5 contained nucleotides 923–3825, pAS-ΔPDZ3–5 contained nucleotides 923–2814, and pAS-ΔPDZ1–5 contained nucleotides 923–1725. DNA constructs for the mammalian two-hybrid assay were made as follows using the plasmid pBIND to express the fusion protein with the GAL4 DNA-binding domain and using pACT to express the fusion protein with the VP16 activation domain. To make pBIND-ActRIIA and pBIND-ActRIIA-N, cDNA fragments encoding the entire cytoplasmic regions of pAS-ActRIIA and pAS-ActRIIA-N were subcloned into pBIND. Mutations in the COOH terminus of ActRIIA were generated by replacing the appropriate nucleotides with mutated oligonucleotides by PCR-based mutagenesis. To make pACT-ARIP1, a cDNA fragment composed of nucleotides 923–4446 of ARIP1, which was prepared by ligating a PCR-generated fragment to a fragment prepared from pBS-ARIP1-short, was subcloned into pACT. ARIP1-short was used throughout the experiment, whereas ARIP1-long was only used in the experiment shown in Fig. 2 A. pACT-ARIP1 (WW), which lacked all of the PDZ domains, contained nucleotides 923–1758 of ARIP1. To make pBIND-Smad3, human Smad3 coding sequences were ligated to pBind. An expression construct of ARIP1 for transcriptional assay was made by subcloning nucleotides 923–4446 of ARIP1 into pcDNA1. FLAG-tagged Smad3 and Smad6 in pcDNA3 were generous gifts from Dr. K. Miyazono. Smad7 in pcDNA3 was obtained from Dr. P. ten Dijke. The 5′ junctional region between the insert and the vector of each construct was sequenced to ensure that the inserts were introduced properly. Yeast two-hybrid assay was performed using a commercially available kit (Matchmaker Two-Hybrid System 2; CLONTECH) according to the manufacturer's protocol. Mammalian two-hybrid assay was performed using CheckMate Mammalian Two-Hybrid System (Promega), according to the manufacturer's protocol. In brief, CHO cells were cotransfected with the plasmids of interest, a cytomegalovirus promoter-driven β-gal (CMV-β-gal) and a reporter plasmid, pG5luc, which drives the luciferase gene under the control of GAL4-responsive promoter (18.Sambrook J. Endocrinology. 1995; 136: 5493-5503Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar). The interaction of full-length ARIP1 and ActRIIA and that of full-length ARIP1 and Smad3 in mammalian cells were studied. COS7 cells were cotransfected with either pcDLSRα-ActRIIA (17.Takebe Y. Seiki M. Fujisawa J. Hoy P. Yokota K. Arai K. Yoshida M. Arai N. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1988; 8: 466-472Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) and CMV-FLAG-ARIP1, or with CMV-6Myc-ARIP1 and CMV-FLAG-Smad3, by the calcium phosphate precipitation method. Two days after transfection, the cells were incubated in a lysis buffer (1% Nonidet P-40, 50 mmTris-HCl (pH 7.5), 150 mm NaCl, 1 mm NaF, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 4 μg/ml leupeptin, and 1 μg/ml aprotinin). The lysate was centrifuged, and the proteins were immunoprecipitated by adding anti-FLAG monoclonal antibody (M2; Sigma) or anti-Myc monoclonal antibody (9E10; Oncogene), and then the samples were incubated with protein A-Sepharose (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) for 2 h at 4 °C. The precipitated proteins were fractionated by SDS-PAGE, and transferred onto a polyvinylidene difluoride membrane. Then the membranes were incubated with an anti-ActRIIA or an anti-FLAG antibody (diluted 1:1000), followed by incubation with a horseradish peroxidase-conjugated second antibody. Labeled proteins were detected by chemiluminescence (ECL-Plus; Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). Cotransfected COS-7 cells were affinity-labeled with 125I-activin A, 2 days after transfection. Radiolabeling of the ligand, affinity cross-linking, and preparation of cell lysates were performed as described previously (19.Hashimoto O. Nakamura T. Shoji H. Shimasaki S. Hayashi Y. Sugino H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 13835-13842Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (169) Google Scholar). Then the beads were washed three times with a lysis buffer. Then precipitated proteins were fractionated by SDS-PAGE and detected by autoradiography. Poly(A)+ RNAs were prepared from various tissues of Balb/c strain mice. RNA (1 μg) from each sample was fractionated and blotted onto a nylon membrane. Endocrinology. 1995; 136: 5493-5503Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar). p3TP-lux, CMV-β-gal, and either pcDNA1-ARIP1 or CMV-FLAG-Smad3 were introduced into human K562 cells by eletroporation. Shubert, The Salk Institute) were transfected with p3TP-lux, CMV-β-gal, and combinations of CMV-FLAG-Smad3 and/or pcDNA1-ARIP1 by using TransFast liposome reagents (Promega) according to the manufacturer's protocol. ARIP1-specific antisera were purified by passing through protein A-Sepharose and were used for immunohistochemistry. Rat hippocampal neuronal cultures were prepared from E18 embryonic rats as described (24.Banker G.A. Cowan W.M. Brain Res. 1977; 126: 397-425Crossref PubMed Scopus (950) Google Scholar). Neuronal cells cultured on poly-l-lysine-coated coverslips were fixed by incubation with 4% paraformaldehyde for 10 min at room temperature, followed by incubation in ice-cold 100% methanol for 5 min. Cells were visualized by immunostaining using rabbit anti-ARIP1 antibody (1:200 dilution), or rabbit anti-ActRIIA antibody (1:200 dilution), or goat anti-Smad2/3 antibody (1:100 dilution, clone E-20 purchased from Santa Cruz). All cells were costained with mouse anti-synaptotagmin I monoclonal antibody (1;400 dilution, mAb1D/2 kindly provided by Dr. M. Takahashi at the Mitsubishi Kasei Institute of Life Scieices) (25.Ono S. Baux G. Sekiguchi M. Fossier P. Morel N.F. Nihonmatsu I. Hirata K. Awaji T. Takahashi S. Takahashi M. Eur. J. Neurosci. 1998; 10: 2143-2152Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). Then, the cells were incubated with fluorescein-conjugated secondary antibody at a 1:400 dilution (Alexa 488 for staining ARIP1, ActRIIA, and Smad2/3 and Alexa 594 for staining synaptotagmin I). Fluorescent images of cells were captured by using a confocal microscope (Leica TCS-NT). In order to investigate intracellular proteins interacting with activin type IIA and/or IIA-N receptors (ActRIIAs), we used yeast two-hybrid system. By screening a library of mouse brain cDNAs fused to the GAL4 activation domain using ActRIIA-N fused with GAL4 DNA-binding domain as a bait, we obtained about 60 positive clones, which we classified into five groups based on restriction fragment analysis. Clones with the longest inserts were selected from each group and were tested for interaction with ActRIIAs in mammalian cells. ActRIIA and candidate clones with the NH2-terminal Myc-epitope in an SRα expression vector were cotransfected in COS-7 cells and the proteins in the cell lysates were immunoprecipitated using an anti-Myc antibody. Only one clone (#YN3) was co-precipitated by ActRIIAs (data not shown). #YN3 contained a 1140-bp insert and encoded one PDZ domain (Fig.1 B). By screening another mouse brain cDNA library using the insert of #YN3 as the hybridization probe, we obtained a full-length cDNA clone of ARIP1-short (pBS-ARIP1-short, Fig. 1 A). The ARIP1-short cDNA encoded a protein of 1112 amino acids, which has two WW domains in the NH2-terminal region, followed by five PDZ domains. #YN3 encoded 228 amino acids, including the entire PDZ5 domain; however, the sequence of #YN3 did not match that of ARIP1 exactly in the COOH-terminal region. The NH2-terminal 213 amino acids of #YN3 were identical to amino acid residues 853–1065 of ARIP1-short, but #YN3 had 15 additional amino acids (AFHSFLHLCSAFSVF) that were not in the ARIP1-short sequence. During the course of this study, Hirao et al. (20.Hirao K. Hata Y. Ide N. Takeuchi M. Irie M. Yao I. Deguchi M. Toyoda A. Sudhof T.C. Takai Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 21105-21110Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (255) Google Scholar) reported the amino acid sequence of a rat homologue of ARIP1, which they named S-SCAM (synaptic scaffolding molecule). S-SCAM is 98.7% identical to the sequence of ARIP1-short when the NH2-terminal region is excluded from the analysis; S-SCAM has an additional 163 NH2-terminal amino acids compared with ARIP1-short. The additional 163 amino acids includes a guanylate kinase domain (Guk). We also detected a long form of ARIP1 in mouse brain by reverse transcription-PCR using a primer synthesized according to the rat S-SCAM sequence, which had the same NH2-terminal sequence as S-SCAM. However, all of the clones we obtained by screening two independent libraries, including two clones from a mouse brain library and 12 clones from a rat brain library, encoded ARIP1-short (data not shown). Thus, it is likely that the short form is more abundant than the long form in mammalian brains. There is an in-frame stop codon 78 base pairs upstream from the boundary site between the long and short form sequences, and those 78 base pairs do not include a start codon. Therefore, we think that translation starts from the first methionine (Fig. 1 A), because this is the first methionine after the stop codon and transcription would then be of the longest reading frame. However, we cannot rule out the possibility that the methionine at amino acid position 60 is the translation start site because the nucleotide sequence near Met-60 agrees well with Kozak's consensus sequences (26.Kozak M Annu. Rev. Cell Biol. 1992; 8: 197-225Crossref PubMed Scopus (415) Google Scholar). ARIP1 interacted with both ActRIIA and ActRIIA-N (Fig. 2, A–C). Deletion from the NH2 terminus to PDZ4 of ARIP1 did not affect its interaction with ActRIIAs (Fig. 2 A). On the other hand, the construct encoding only PDZ5 was able to interact with ARIP1, and deletion of PDZ5 from ARIP1 resulted in the complete loss of interaction with ActRIIA or ActRIIA-N. These results indicate that ARIP1 interacts with ActRIIA and ActRIIA-N through PDZ5. Previously characterized PDZ domains recognize a class I consensus PDZ-binding motif, XSX(V/I/L) (where X is any amino acid), at the COOH terminus of the target proteins (27.Saras J. Heldin C.H. Trends. Biochem. Sci. 1996; 21: 455-458Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (222) Google Scholar, 28.Songyang Z. Fanning A.S. Fu C. Xu J. Marfatia S.M. Chishti A.H. Crompton A. Chan A.C. Anderson J.M. Cantley L.C. Science. 1997; 275: 73-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (1219) Google Scholar). The four COOH-terminal amino acids of ActRIIAs are ESSL, which agrees with the consensus PDZ-binding sequence. In the present study, ARIP1 did not interact with mutated ActRIIA proteins that lacked either the COOH-terminal SSL or the COOH-terminal leucine (Fig. 2 B). Thus, the COOH-terminal amino acids of the receptors play a central role in the interaction of ARIP1 with ActRIIAs through PDZ5. ARIP1 did not interact significantly with ActRIIB, bone morphogenetic protein type II receptor, or the TGF-β type II receptor in the mammalian two-hybrid system (Fig. 2 C). In addition, ARIP1 did not interact with ActRIA and ActRIB in the yeast system (data not shown). These results indicate that ARIP1 interacts specifically with ActRIIA and ActRIIA-N among the serine/threonine kinase receptors for the TGF-β family and that this interaction can occur in both yeast cells and mammalian cells. When lysates of ActRIIA and FLAG-tagged ARIP1 cotransfected COS7 cells were incubated with an anti-FLAG antibody, the immunoprecipitated protein was detected by an anti-ActRIIA antibody, which confirmed that ActRIIA and ARIP1 formed a protein complex in the transfected cells (Fig. 2 D). Because many PDZ domain-containing proteins have a role in assembling receptors and signaling molecules in the cell membrane and in the submembranous region, we next investigated the interaction of ARIP1 with an intracellular signaling molecule Smad in mammalian cells. Smads are classified into 3 groups, signal-specific Smads (Smad2 and Smad3 for activin and TGF-β and Smad1, Smad5, and Smad8 for bone morphogenetic proteins), common-mediator Smad (Smad4), and inhibitory Smads (Smad6 and Smad7). Among them, Smad3 is shown to transiently associate with activin type IB and TGF-β type I receptor and to be phosphorylated by the type I receptors to propagate downstream signaling (29.Heldin C.H. Miyazono K. ten Dijke P. Nature. 1997; 390: 465-471Crossref PubMed Scopus (3341) Google Scholar). We observed a specific interaction between Smad3 and ARIP1 in CHO cells transfected with a full-length Smad3 cDNA fused to the GAL4 DNA-binding domain and ARIP1 fused to the VP16 activation domain in the mammalian two-hybrid system (Fig.3 A). Because Smad3 does not contain a consensus PDZ-binding sequence in its COOH-terminal region, it is likely that Smad3 associates with ARIP1 through a region other than PDZ domains. As expected, Smad3 interacted with an ARIP1 mutant that lacked all five PDZ domains but retained the WW domains (Fig.3 A). The direct interaction of the FLAG-Smad3 and Myc-ARIP1 in transfected COS-7 cells was confirmed by immunoprecipitation with an anti-FLAG antibody, followed by blotting with an anti-Myc antibody (Fig. 3 B). Smad2 also interacted with ARIP1 but not as strongly as did Smad3 (data not shown). To detect the association of ARIP1 and Smad3 in the activin receptor complex in the presence of ligand, affinity labeling with125I-activin A was performed. When COS-7 cells cotransfected with ActRIIA, ActRIB(K234R) (8.Tsuchida K. Vaughan J.M. Wiater E. Gaddy-Kurten D. Vale W.W. Endocrinology. 1995; 136: 5493-5503Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar), 6Myc-ARIP1, and FLAG-Smad3 were incubated in the presence of 125I-activin A, the 125I-labeled receptor complex could be precipitated by either of the anti-Myc and anti-FLAG antibodies (Fig.3 C). Therefore, ARIP1 is capable of forming a complex with ActRIIA, ActRIB, and Smad3 in the presence of ligand. Northern blots of poly(A)+ RNA extracted from several mouse tissues showed ARIP1 mRNA of approximately 7.5 and 6.5 kilobases. Both bands were distinct in the brain and faint in the heart and testis (Fig. 4). Thus, ARIP1 mRNA is more abundant in neuronal tissues than in other tissues. The two mRNA species seen in the Northern blot probably reflect differences in the 3′-noncoding regions, because two groups of cDNAs isolated by cloning had 3′-noncoding regions of different lengths. Human K562 erythroleukemia cells, the proliferation and differentiation of which are regulated by activin, were transfected with pcDNA1-ARIP1 together with a reporter plasmid p3TP-lux, and activin-induced luciferase activity was measured. Overexpression of ARIP1 by transfected K562 cells decreased the activin-induced transcriptional activity in a dose-dependent manner (Fig.5 A). However, Smad7, which is a potent negative regulator of intracellular signal transduction by activin and TGF-β, inhibited the activin-induced transcriptional induction more potently than did ARIP1. Inhibition by ARIP1 was comparable with that of Smad6, which is also an inhibitory Smad for TGF-β and bone morphogenetic proteins. Because ARIP1 is predominantly expressed in neuronal tissues and has been suggested to have a role in synaptic transmission in the hippocampus and other brain regions (20.Hirao K. Hata Y. Ide N. Takeuchi M. Irie M. Yao I. Deguchi M. Toyoda A. Sudhof T.C. Takai Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 21105-21110Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (255) Google Scholar), we have investigated the effects of ARIP1 in activin signaling in hippocampus-derived cell line, HT22, which expresses ARIP1 endogenously (30.Sagara Y. Schubert D. J. Neurosci. 1998; 18: 6662-6671Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) (data not shown). Activin induced a 3TP-lux transcriptional response in HT22 cells (Fig. 5 B). Although overexpression of ARIP1 barely affected the response to activin, it did significantly suppress Smad3-induced augmentation of the transcriptional response to activin (Fig. 5 B). Because ARIP1 is capable of binding Smad3 (Fig. 3), it seems likely that ARIP1 bound Smad3 in the HT22 cells and thus prevented Smad3 to exert transcriptional response in the nucleus. In order to investigate the cellular localization of ARIP1 protein, rabbit polyclonal antisera were prepared and were used for immunohistochemistry in cultured rat hippocampal primary neurons. As shown in Fig. 6, A–C,double-immunostaining of hippocampal cells by ARIP1 and synaptotagmin I antibodies showed that ARIP1 immunoreactivity is present primarily in neurons, especially in synaptic areas. Costained images were also obtained when cells were double-immunostained either by ActRIIA and synaptotagmin I antibodies (Fig. 6, D–F) or by Smad 2/3 and synaptotagmin I antibodies (Fig. 6, G–I), suggesting that ARIP1 colocalizes with ActRIIA and Smad3 in hippocampal neurons. We have isolated and characterized a mouse PDZ protein, which we named ARIP1, that interacts with ActRIIA and ActRIIA-N. This is the first report of a molecule that associates with type II activin receptors, although a WD-domain-containing protein (TRIP1) that interacted with the TGF-β type II receptor has been reported (31.Chen R.H. Miettinen P.J. Maruoka E.M. Choy L. Derynck R. Nature. 1995; 377: 548-552Crossref PubMed Scopus (175) Google Scholar). We detected two forms of ARIP1, ARIP1-long and ARIP1-short, which differed in their NH2-terminal sequences. Each form interacted with both ActRIIA and ActRIIA-N. Recently, the rat and human homologues of the mouse ARIP1 gene have been found. The rat protein, called S-SCAM, is a scaffolding synaptic molecule that interacts withN-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptors (20.Hirao K. Hata Y. Ide N. Takeuchi M. Irie M. Yao I. Deguchi M. Toyoda A. Sudhof T.C. Takai Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 21105-21110Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (255) Google Scholar). The human homologue, called AIP1, associates with atrophin, which is responsible for the pathogenesis of CAG triplet disease, called dentatorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy (32.Wood J.D. Yuan J. Margolis R.L. Colomer V. Duan K. Kushi J. Kaminsky Z. Kleiderlein J.J. Sharp A.H. Ross C.A. Mol. Cell. Neurosci. 1998; 11: 149-160Crossref PubMed Scopus (136) Google Scholar). cDNAs for S-SCAM and AIP1 encode proteins that correspond to ARIP1-long. In the present study, ARIP1-long was detected only by reverse transcription-PCR and all of the cDNA clones obtained by library screening, which covered the entire protein-coding region, encoded ARIP1-short. Therefore, ARIP1-short seems to be the major mRNA species in mammalian brain. The isoforms of ARIP1 are probably produced by alternative splicing, because their nucleotide sequences are dissimilar from the junction site to the 5′ end. The inconsistency observed in 3′ region of #YN3 and ARIP1-short appears to have been produced by alternative splicing as well, because their cDNA sequences are dissimilar from the junction site to the 3′ end. A mouse protein called MAGI-1 has a domain organization similar to that of ARIP1 (33.Dobrosotskaya I. Guy R.K. James G.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 31589-31597Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar), which suggests that the genes encoding these two proteins belong to the same gene family. Our analysis of the interactions between mutant ARIP1 proteins and ActRIIA showed that ARIP1 interacts with the COOH terminus of ActRIIAs mainly via the PDZ5 domain. The three COOH-terminal amino acids of ActRIIAs, which are consistent with the consensus PDZ-binding motif, were critical for this interaction (Fig. 2 B). The PDZ5 domain of ARIP1 seemed to prefer leucine to isoleucine in the COOH terminus of the target protein; we did not detect significant interaction between ARIP1 and ActRIIB, which has the COOH-terminal sequence ESSI. On the other hand, S-SCAM was originally cloned by its activity to bind to a postsynaptic protein, SAPAP (SAP90/postsynaptic density-95-associated proteins), through a Guk domain. In addition, S-SCAM interacts with the COOH termini of the 2A and 2C subunits of NMDA receptors (NR2A and NR2C) through PDZ5 (20.Hirao K. Hata Y. Ide N. Takeuchi M. Irie M. Yao I. Deguchi M. Toyoda A. Sudhof T.C. Takai Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 21105-21110Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (255) Google Scholar). The COOH-terminal sequences of NR2A and NR2C are ESDV and ESEV, respectively, which are consistent with the consensus PDZ-binding motif. Whether ActRIIA and the NMDA receptors associate with ARIP1 cooperatively or compete with each other remains to be determined. Interestingly, ARIP1 associated with Smad proteins. The WW domains of ARIP1 interacted with Smad3 specifically (Fig. 3 A). WW domains prefer to bind to a proline-rich sequence, called the PY motif (PPXY) (34.Pirozzi G. McConnell S.J. Uveges A.J. Carter J.M. Sparks A.B. Kay B.K. Fowlkes D.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 14611-14616Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar), and Smad proteins have a PY motif in the linker region (29.Heldin C.H. Miyazono K. ten Dijke P. Nature. 1997; 390: 465-471Crossref PubMed Scopus (3341) Google Scholar), so it makes sense that ARIP1 and Smad3 interacted. Smad3 associates transiently with and is phosphorylated by activated ActRIB and by the TGF-β type I receptor, which triggers intracellular signaling. Because different domains of ARIP1 are responsible for its association with ActRIIA and with Smad3 (Fig. 3), a quaternary complex of ActRIIA, ActRIB, Smad3, and ARIP1 can form. Thus, the biological function of ARIP1 is likely to be the assembly of a macromolecular structure composed of two types of activin receptor and an intracellular signaling molecule for activin signal transduction in the cell membrane and in the submembranous region. The way of ARIP1 assembles membrane proteins is reminiscent of the Drosophila PDZ protein, InaD. InaD, which has multiple PDZ domains, acts as a scaffold for rhodopsin, a calcium channel, protein kinase C, and phospholipase C in phototransduction cascades (35.Tsunoda S. Sierralta J. Sun Y. Bodner R. Suzuki E. Becker A. Socolich M. Zuker C.S. Nature. 1997; 388: 243-249Crossref PubMed Scopus (551) Google Scholar). Recently, a protein that has an FYVE-domain, called SARA (Smad anchor for receptor activation), was identified in a study of TGF-β signaling. SARA associates with TGF-β receptors and Smad and regulates TGF-β signaling (36.Tsukazaki T. Chiang T.A. Davison A.F. Attisano L. Wrana J.L. Cell. 1998; 95: 779-791Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (787) Google Scholar). Because SARA and ARIP1 do not show any structural similarities, these proteins probably regulate receptor serine/threonine kinases in different ways. We have shown that ARIP1 mRNA is abundant in mouse brain, and we also detected low amounts of ARIP1 in kidney, lung, heart, and testis. Therefore, ARIP1 is predominantly expressed in brain compared with the other tissues. Overexpression of ARIP1 reduced activin-induced transcription in human K562 cells (Fig. 5 A) and suppressed Smad3-augmented transcription in a mouse hippocampus-derived HT 22 cells (Fig.5 B); thus, ARIP1 may regulate activin-induced signaling in neuronal cells. Whether ARIP1 inhibits signal transduction under physiological conditions remains to be determined; nevertheless, it is a fascinating idea that ARIP1 could be involved in the activation and/or deactivation of activin signaling in neuronal cells, like InaD in the phototransduction cascade (37.Shieh B.H. Zhu M.Y. Lee J.K. Kelly I.M. Bahiraei F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 12682-12687Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). ARIP1 has multiple protein-protein interaction domains and can recruit Smad3 as well as binding to activin receptors; thus, ARIP1 may be the scaffold of the activin-signaling complex in the cell membrane and in the submembranous region and participate in a physiological regulation of signal transduction. S-SCAM, the rat homologue of ARIP1, binds the postsynaptic protein SAPAP; thus, it may have a role in synaptic transmission (20.Hirao K. Hata Y. Ide N. Takeuchi M. Irie M. Yao I. Deguchi M. Toyoda A. Sudhof T.C. Takai Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 21105-21110Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (255) Google Scholar). The postsynaptic membrane has a dense thickening of submembranous cytoskeleton, called postsynaptic density, that is essential for the localization of neurotransmitter receptors and ion channels. SAPAP is thought to have a central role in the formation of postsynaptic density (38.Takeuchi M. Hata Y. Hirao K. Toyoda A. Irie M. Takai Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 11943-11951Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar). S-SCAM also interacts with the other postsynaptic density components, including NMDA receptor subunits and a neuronal cell adhesion molecule, neuroligin-1 (20.Hirao K. Hata Y. Ide N. Takeuchi M. Irie M. Yao I. Deguchi M. Toyoda A. Sudhof T.C. Takai Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 21105-21110Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (255) Google Scholar). The emergence of adapter and scaffolding proteins as critical functional elements of cellular signaling processes suggests that an important principle of signal transduction lies in the spatial organization of transmembrane receptors and ion channels. ARIP1 (S-SCAM) must be one of the molecules responsible for the macromolecular organization of signaling components in neuronal cells. Activins and their receptors were first characterized as essential regulatory molecules of the hypothalamus-pituitary-gonadal axis. However, recent investigations have shown that activins also have roles in nervous system organization. Expression of mRNA for the activin βA subunit increases in the hippocampus during long-term potentiation (39.Inokuchi K. Kato A. Hiraia K. Hishinuma F. Inoue M. Ozawa F. FEBS Lett. 1996; 382: 48-52Crossref PubMed Scopus (75) Google Scholar) and following hippocampal lesion (40.Tretter Y.P. Munz B. Hubner G. ten Bruggencate G. Werner S. Alzheimer C. Neuroreport. 1996; 7: 1819-1823Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar) in an NMDA-dependent manner. Furthermore, activin regulates neurotransmitter phenotype of sympathetic neurons (6.Link B.A. Nishi R. Dev. Biol. 1998; 199: 226-234Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar, 7.Fann M.J. Patterson P.H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 43-47Crossref PubMed Scopus (148) Google Scholar). Thus, it is likely that activin regulates neurotransmission by controlling neurotransmitter release from the presynaptic neuron and/or by influencing the efficacy of postsynaptic transmission, leading to the formation of active synapses and the acquisition of learning and memory. Our characterization of ARIP1 as the scaffold of a complex of activin receptors and a Smad protein in neuronal cells not only presents a novel mode of regulation of receptor serine/threonine kinases but will also help to clarify the neuronal functions of activins and other members of the TGF-β family.
