The ethanol-induced increase in MII formation was amplified by the addition of neutral osmolytes. This enhancement was linear with osmolality. At 360 milliosmolal, the osmolality of human plasma, 50 mm ethanol was 2.7 times more potent than at 0 osmolality, demonstrating the importance of water activity in in vitro experiments dealing with ethanol potency. Ethanol disordered acyl chain packing, and increasing osmolality enhanced this acyl chain disordering. Prior osmotic stress data showed a release of 35 ± 2 water molecules upon MII formation. Ethanol increases this number to 49 water molecules, suggesting that ethanol replaces 15 additional water molecules upon MII formation. Amplification of ethanol effects on MII formation and acyl chain packing by osmolytes suggests that ethanol increases the equilibrium concentration of MII both by disordering acyl chain packing and by disrupting rhodopsin-water hydrogen bonds, demonstrating a direct effect of ethanol on rhodopsin. At physiologically relevant levels of osmolality and ethanol, about 90% of ethanol's effect is due to disordered acyl chain packing. metarhodopsin I metarhodopsin II rod outer segment 1,6-diphenyl-1,3,5-hexatriene One of the proposed modes of action of ethanol on biological macromolecules and membranes involves the replacement of hydrogen-bonded water by ethanol (1.Eyring H. Woodbury J.W. D'Arrigo J.S. Anesthesiology. 1973; 38: 415-424Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar, 2.Klemm W.R. Alcohol. 1998; 15: 249-267Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). Based on the hydrogen bonding capability of both water and ethanol, it is postulated that they compete for hydrogen bonding sites on the surface of lipids and proteins. Thus, this action of ethanol is equally applicable to mechanisms of ethanol action involving both lipid-mediated and direct protein interactions. The general importance of changes in hydration in enzyme activity is widely acknowledged (3.$$$$$$ ref data missingGoogle Scholar, 4.Timasheff S.N. Annu. Rev. Biophys. Biomol. Struct. 1993; 22: 67-97Crossref PubMed Scopus (965) Google Scholar), but there is little detailed knowledge regarding how replacement of water by ethanol in specific protein-water hydrogen bonds might alter protein conformational equilibria or function. In addition, the physical properties of the surrounding phospholipid bilayer are known to modulate membrane function. Ethanol-induced changes in phospholipid hydrogen bonding have been observed to change acyl chain packing in pure lipid bilayers (5.Chiou J-S. Ma S-M. Kamaya H. Ueda I. Science. 1990; 248: 583-585Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar, 6.Chiou J-S. Krishna P.R. Kamaya H. Ueda I. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1992; 1110: 225-233Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar, 7.Slater S.J. Ho C. Taddeo F.J. Kelly M.B. Stubbs C.D. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 3714-3721Crossref PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar). Thus, the function of integral membrane receptors could be especially susceptible to the disruption of hydrogen-bonded water by ethanol. Thorough examination of the interplay between ethanol and hydration in modulating membrane receptor function requires the ability to separately analyze the effects of ethanol on both protein structure and bilayer physical properties and to be able to correlate the observed changes. Previously, we examined the effects of ethanol (8.Mitchell D.C. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 12752-12756Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar) and a series of n-alkanols (9.Mitchell D.C. Lawrence J.T.R. Litman B.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 19033-19036Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar) on both the MI1-MII conformational equilibrium and acyl chain packing in the surrounding bilayer. In the present work, the effects of ethanol on the MI-MII equilibrium and acyl chain packing are reexamined as a function of osmotic stress. The osmotic stress protocol (10.Parsegian V.A. Rand R.P. Rau D.C. Methods Enzymol. 1995; 259: 43-94Crossref PubMed Scopus (372) Google Scholar) is an established method for determining changes in the number of bound water molecules associated with a specific enzymatic process. This experimental strategy is based on the fact that the effect of a neutral osmolyte on the water activity of aqueous compartments in equilibrium with a protein depends on the degree to which it is excluded from the protein-associated water. Osmolyte inaccessibility is determined by the protein topology and the size of the osmolyte (11.Arakawa T. Timasheff S.N. Biochemistry. 1985; 24: 6756-6762Crossref PubMed Scopus (405) Google Scholar). The result is that by reducing the activity of water, the presence of an osmotically active osmolyte inhibits protein conformational changes in which there is a net uptake of water and favors processes in which a protein releases water to the bulk aqueous medium. Osmolytes, which are so small that they are not excluded from any clefts or pockets on the protein surface, will not be osmotically active (12.Rand R.P. Fuller N.L. Butko P. Francis G. Nicholls P. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 5925-5929Crossref PubMed Scopus (131) Google Scholar). Recently, we employed this technique to show that the MI to MII transition of photoactivated rhodopsin is dependent upon water activity, with the MII conformation binding 35 ± 2 fewer water molecules than MI (13.Mitchell D.C. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 7617-7623Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). Rhodopsin resides in the retinal ROS disc membrane, where it represents about 95% of the integral membrane protein. About half of its mass is within the lipid bilayer, while the other half makes up the hydrophilic loops, connecting the α-helices. The detailed structural information obtained recently for both the loops (14.Yeagle P.L. Alderfer J.L. Albert A.D. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 9649-9654Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar) and the transmembrane helices (15.Schertler G.F.X. Hargrave P.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 11578-11582Crossref PubMed Scopus (217) Google Scholar, 16.Unger V.M. Hargrave P.A. Baldwin J.M. Schertler G.F.X. Nature. 1997; 389: 203-206Crossref PubMed Scopus (479) Google Scholar) makes rhodopsin the most well characterized member of the G protein-coupled receptor superfamily. Within a few milliseconds of light absorption, a metastable equilibrium is established between MII, the conformation which binds and activates transducin (17.Kibelbek J. Mitchell D.C. Beach J.M. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 6761-6768Crossref PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar), and its inactive precursor, MI (18.Mathews R. Hubbard R. Brown P. Wald G. J. Gen. Physiol. 1963; 47: 215-222Crossref PubMed Scopus (427) Google Scholar). The MI-to-MII conformational change is the principal conformation change of photolyzed rhodopsin, and many details of this structural change have been determined (19.Litman B.J. Mitchell D.C. Lee A. Biomembranes. 2A. JAI Press, Greeenwich, CT1996: 1-32Google Scholar), including changes in the hydrogen bonding of internal water molecules (20.Rath P. Delange F. DeGrip W.J. Rothschild K.J. Biochem. J. 1998; 329: 713-717Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar, 21.Maeda A. Ohkita Y.J. Sasaki J. Shichida Y. Yoshizawa T. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 12033-12038Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). Previous studies have determined the sensitivity of MII formation with respect to both bilayer composition and phospholipid bilayer acyl chain packing (22.Mitchell D.C. Straume M. Miller J.L. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 9143-9149Crossref PubMed Scopus (148) Google Scholar, 23.Mitchell D.C. Straume M. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 662-670Crossref PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar, 24.Litman B.J. Mitchell D.C. Lipids. 1996; 31 (suppl.): 193Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The available structural information for rhodopsin coupled with its central role in visual transduction and its relationship to neurotransmitter receptors make rhodopsin an ideal receptor on which to study the interplay between hydration and ethanol. Ethanol and osmotic stress have opposite effects on acyl chain packing. The ability of ethanol to disorder phospholipid acyl chain packing has been measured in a large number of natural and artificial membranes by several techniques (8.Mitchell D.C. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 12752-12756Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar, 9.Mitchell D.C. Lawrence J.T.R. Litman B.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 19033-19036Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar, 25.Miller K.W. Int. Rev. Neurobiol. 1985; 270: 1-61Google Scholar). In contrast, osmotic stress, or lowered water activity, leads to increased phospholipid acyl chain packing with a concomitant reduction in bilayer free volume (13.Mitchell D.C. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 7617-7623Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar, 26.Lehtonen J.Y.A. Kinnunen K.J. Biophys. J. 1994; 66: 1981-1990Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar). A complicating factor in most ethanol experiments, which obscures their relevance toin vivo effects, is that they are generally performed on dilute aqueous suspensions of membranes or artificial vesicles. In such experiments, the potential for in vivo osmotic conditions to alter water activity and thereby change the effect of ethanol on membranes is left in question. In this study, we examined the combined effects of ethanol and osmotic stress on both the activating conformational change of the G protein-coupled receptor rhodopsin (i.e. the formation of MII) and on acyl chain packing of the ROS disc membrane. Intact ROS disks were prepared from frozen bovine retinas as described previously (27.Smith H.G. Litman B.J. Methods Enzymol. 1982; 81: 57-61Crossref PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar). Stachyose was purchased from Sigma, and DPH was purchased from Molecular Probes, Inc. (Eugene, OR). Samples for all studies (8 μm rhodopsin for all absorbance measurements, 1.2 μm rhodopsin for fluorescence measurements) were prepared in a low ionic strength buffer (10 mm HEPES, 50 μmdiethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid, pH 7.5) with the required osmolyte. Osmolyte-containing samples were then put through 10 freeze-thaw cycles to ensure that the osmolyte had equilibrated across the membrane and then were extruded through a 0.2-μm pore filter 10 times to reduce scattered light. All procedures were carried out under argon in a glove box to minimize oxidation of the polyunsaturated acyl chains of the ROS disc membrane. The osmolality of all solutions was determined with a Wescor Vapro 5520 vapor pressure osmometer. Absorbance spectra of MI-MII equilibrium mixtures ∼3 s following a flash that bleached 15–20% of the rhodopsin were acquired with a Hewlett-Packard 8452A diode array spectrophotometer (0.2-s measurements yielded <0.3% bleach by measuring beam) (28.Straume M. Mitchell D.C. Miller J.L. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 9135-9142Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar). Individual MI and MII bands were resolved by using nonlinear least squares to fit the sum of two asymmetric Gaussian absorbance bands to difference spectra that had been corrected for the presence of unbleached rhodopsin (28.Straume M. Mitchell D.C. Miller J.L. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 9135-9142Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar). The equilibrium constant for the MI to MII conversion is defined byK eq = [MII]/[MI]. In determining the effect of neutral osmolytes, the ethanol-free osmolyte solution served as the control; thus, when examining effects of the osmolytes on the ethanol-induced MII formation, the solution osmolality does not include the contribution due to ethanol. The change in free energy, Δ(ΔG), for the MI-MII equilibrium due to the presence of ethanol was calculated according to the following. Δ(ΔG)=ΔGethanol−ΔGethanol­free controlEquation 1 The effect of osmotic stress on the MI-MII equilibrium was analyzed using established thermodynamic relationships (10.Parsegian V.A. Rand R.P. Rau D.C. Methods Enzymol. 1995; 259: 43-94Crossref PubMed Scopus (372) Google Scholar). The change in the number of water molecules in osmolyte-inaccessible regions, ΔN w, is given by the slope of line relating ln(K eq) and the osmolyte concentration as follows. ln(K eq)=−ΔNw×[osmolal]55.6Equation 2 Fluorescence lifetime and differential polarization measurements were performed with an ISS K2 multifrequency cross-correlation phase fluorometer with excitation provided by an Innova 307 Argon ion laser (Coherent). Lifetime and differential polarization data were acquired using 15 modulation frequencies, logarithmically spaced from 5 to 250 MHz. Scattered excitation light was removed from the emission beam by a 390-nm high pass filter. All lifetime measurements were made with the emission polarizer at 54.7° relative to the vertically polarized excitation beam and with 1,4-bis(5-phenyloxazol-2-yl)benzene in absolute ethanol in the reference cuvette. For each differential polarization measurement, the instrumental polarization factors were measured and found to be between 1 and 1.05, and the appropriate correction factor was applied. At each frequency, data were accumulated until the S.D. values of the phase and modulation ratio were below 0.2° and 0.004, respectively, and these values were used as the S.D. for the measured phases and modulation ratios in all subsequent analysis. Both total intensity decay and differential polarization measurements were repeated a minimum of three times. Measured polarization-dependent differential phases and modulation ratios for each sample were combined with the measured total intensity decay to yield the anisotropy decay,r(t). All anisotropy decay data were analyzed using the Brownian rotational diffusion model as described previously (29.Mitchell D.C. Litman B.J. Biophys. J. 1998; 74: 879-891Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar). The results of the Brownian rotational diffusion model-based analysis were interpreted in terms of an angular distribution function,f(θ), which is symmetric about θ = π/2 (29.Mitchell D.C. Litman B.J. Biophys. J. 1998; 74: 879-891Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar). The extent to which the equilibrium orientational freedom of DPH is restricted by the phospholipid acyl chains was quantified using the parameter f v (30.Straume M. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1987; 26: 5113-5120Crossref PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar), which is defined as follows. fv=1/(2f (θ) max)Equation 3 All measurements were performed at 20 °C, and all data analysis were performed with NONLIN (31.Johnson M.L. Frasier S.G. Methods Enzymol. 1985; 117: 301-342Crossref Scopus (507) Google Scholar), with all subroutines specifying the fitting functions written by the authors. Confidence intervals corresponding to 1 S.D. were obtained by NONLIN for both fitting variables and derived parameters. The bilayer correction to account for the effect of altered phospholipid acyl chain packing on Δ(ΔG) was calculated using the known relationship between Δ(ΔG) and f vinduced by varying independently both ethanol concentration and osmotic pressure. These relationships allowed the determination of (∂ΔG/∂f vEtOH) and (∂ΔG/∂f vOs), respectively. Specifically, the measured changes inf v due to the presence of osmolytes were subtracted from the observed changes in f v due to the presence of both osmolyte and ethanol to obtain the value of Δf vEtOH. This allowed the inclusion of the enhanced effect of ethanol induced by the presence of the osmolyte. Δ(ΔG)bilayer was calculated according to Equation 4. Δ(ΔG) bilayer=ΔfvOs(∂ΔG/∂fvOs)+ΔfvEtOH(∂ΔG/∂fvEtOH)Equation 4 Previous studies showed that both neutral osmolytes (13.Mitchell D.C. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 7617-7623Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar) and ethanol (8.Mitchell D.C. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 12752-12756Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar, 9.Mitchell D.C. Lawrence J.T.R. Litman B.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 19033-19036Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar) shift the MI-MII equilibrium toward MII. In order to compare the combined effect of ethanol and osmolytes on the MI-MII equilibrium, the observed shifts in K eqwere converted to differences in the change in free energy in the presence and absence of ethanol, Δ(ΔG) (Equation 1). In the absence of osmolyte, increasing the ethanol concentration made Δ(ΔG) more negative (i.e. ethanol shifted the MI-MII equilibrium toward MII), as shown by the control curve for 0 sucrose in Fig. 1. The effect of ethanol was amplified by the presence of neutral osmolyte, as shown by the curves for sucrose and stachyose (Fig. 1). Increasing osmolyte concentration reduces water activity. The effect of decreasing water activity on the efficacy of ethanol is demonstrated by plotting Δ(ΔG) due to ethanol as a function of increasing osmolality for four different ethanol concentrations, Fig.2. The effect of 50, 100, 300, and 500 mm ethanol on the MI-MII equilibrium increased approximately linearly with increasing osmolality. Solution osmolality was varied with sucrose, except for where shown by the open symbols, which correspond to stachyose solutions. An earlier investigation of the effects of osmotic stress showed that the influence of sucrose and stachyose on the MI-MII equilibrium is equivalent at the same osmolal concentration (13.Mitchell D.C. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 7617-7623Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). The clear trend of decreasing Δ(ΔG) with increasing osmolality for both sucrose and stachyose (Fig. 2) demonstrates that at a given ethanol concentration, reduced water activity enhances the ability of ethanol to promote the formation of the MII conformation.Figure 2Osmolality enhances the effect of ethanol on Δ(ΔG) for the MI to MII transition. Filled symbolsrepresent sucrose solutions; open symbolsrepresent stachyose solutions. ▴, 50 mm ethanol; ●, 100 mm ethanol; ▾, 300 mm ethanol; ▪, 500 mm ethanol.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) The effect of solute osmolality on ethanol-induced phospholipid acyl chain disordering was assessed by analyzing the fluorescence lifetime and anisotropy decay of DPH under the same osmolyte and ethanol conditions used to study the MI-MII equilibrium. The DPH fluorescence lifetime was well characterized by a decay scheme consisting of a Lorentzian distribution plus two discrete components, which produced values of χ2 between 0.9 and 2.5. The lifetimes of the two discrete components ranged from 2.2 to 1.4 ns and from 0.27 to 0.22 ns, respectively, and together they accounted for 10–15% of the decay under all conditions. The high concentration of rhodopsin in the ROS disc membrane (1 rhodopsin per 75 phospholipids) results in substantial quenching of the DPH fluorescence due to energy transfer to the retinal chromophore. This quenching of DPH fluorescence by retinal is the probable source of the two short lifetime components. In the absence of ethanol, the center of the Lorentzian distribution ranged from 9.1 to 9.5 ns under all osmolyte conditions, and the maximum change was seen in 500 mm ethanol where this value was reduced by about 0.3 ns for all osmolyte conditions. The effect of ethanol on the decay of fluorescence anisotropy,r(t), was also increased by the addition of osmolyte. The Brownian rotational diffusion model characterizesr(t) in terms of the equilibrium orientational distribution of the probe, f(θ), and the rotational diffusion coefficient, D⊥ (29.Mitchell D.C. Litman B.J. Biophys. J. 1998; 74: 879-891Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar). For a free-tumbling probe like DPH, f(θ) is especially informative regarding acyl chain packing, because f(θ) consists of the set of angular orientations that DPH is allowed to adopt within the confines of the ensemble packing of the phospholipid acyl chains. The shape of the orientation probability distribution, f(θ) sinθ, provides information about relative acyl chain packing density at different depths in the bilayer, and the extent of overlap off(θ) sinθ with a random orientational distribution indicates the degree of overall ordering of DPH by the acyl chains. Individually, neutral osmolytes and ethanol had large and opposite effects on f(θ) sinθ, as shown by comparing the curve for 0 osmolyte, 0 ethanol with those for 0 osmolyte, 500 mmethanol, and 1440 mOsm sucrose, 0 ethanol in Fig.3 A. Osmolytes narrowed the unimodal distribution centered about the membrane normal, while ethanol broadened the distribution, and this broadening was enhanced by the presence of osmolyte, as shown by the curve for 1440 mOsm, 500 mm ethanol. However, the disordering effect of ethanol was not strong enough to fully reverse the ordering effect of the osmolyte. An example of the manner in which reduced water activity enhanced the ethanol-induced changes in f(θ) sinθ is shown by the difference curves in Fig. 3 B, which demonstrate the net effect on f(θ) sinθ of 100 mm ethanol for four different solute osmolalities. The curves in Fig. 3 Bwere obtained by subtracting f(θ) sinθ obtained with the specified solute osmolality in the absence of ethanol from the distribution obtained in the presence of 100 mm ethanol at the corresponding solute osmolality. Areas below thezero line in Fig. 3 B correspond to angular orientations from which the DPH is excluded in the presence of ethanol, and areas above the zero linedenote angular orientations that are preferentially allowed by the bilayer in the presence of ethanol. Ethanol enhanced DPH orientations greater than ∼20° from the membrane normal, and an increase in the concentration of added osmolyte amplified this effect. As the osmolyte concentration was increased, 100 mm ethanol progressively broadened the probability distribution centered about the membrane normal. A convenient, quantitative means of comparing different orientational probability distributions is the parameter f v(Equation 3), which is proportional to the overlap of f(θ) sinθ for a given sample and f(θ) sinθ of a random distribution (29.Mitchell D.C. Litman B.J. Biophys. J. 1998; 74: 879-891Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar), and thus is a measure of ensemble acyl chain order. A higher value of f v indicates an orientational distribution that is more like a random distribution. The separate effects of ethanol and the reduced water activity caused by increased osmolality on f v are antagonistic, with ethanol causing an increase in f v (8.Mitchell D.C. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 12752-12756Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar, 9.Mitchell D.C. Lawrence J.T.R. Litman B.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 19033-19036Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar), while in the absence of ethanol, reduced water activity lowers f v(13.Mitchell D.C. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 7617-7623Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). However, the net result of these two factors acting simultaneously is that the effect of ethanol is amplified by reduced water activity, as shown in Fig. 4. At 330 mOsm, the effect of 50 and 100 mm ethanol is increased by about a factor of 2.5, relative to dilute buffer conditions. Previous investigations demonstrated a direct correlation between the MI-MII equilibrium constant and f v, when both parameters are altered by changes in temperature or bilayer cholesterol content (22.Mitchell D.C. Straume M. Miller J.L. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 9143-9149Crossref PubMed Scopus (148) Google Scholar, 23.Mitchell D.C. Straume M. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 662-670Crossref PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar, 24.Litman B.J. Mitchell D.C. Lipids. 1996; 31 (suppl.): 193Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In order to examine the relationship between ethanol-induced changes in acyl chain packing and in the MI-MII equilibrium, values of Δ(ΔG) and Δf v due to ethanol were plotted against each other for each solute osmolality (Fig. 5). As the concentration of ethanol increases at each osmolality, the Δ(ΔG) values become more negative and the Δf v values become larger. For 0 mOsm, the correlation is linear; however, as the osmolality increases, this relationship becomes increasingly nonlinear. This nonlinearity suggests that Δ(ΔG) is being influenced by some factor in addition to the ethanol-induced changes in bilayer acyl chain order, reflected in the increase in f v. One of the important issues in in vitro studies of the mechanism(s) of ethanol's action on biological systems is the biologically relevant range of concentrations of ethanol (32.Deitrich R.A. Harris R.A. Alcohol Clin. Exp. Res. 1996; 20: 1-2Crossref PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar). The present data can be used to address this issue by considering the osmolality-induced increase in ethanol potency observed when measurements made in the presence of a neutral osmolyte, at the osmolality of human plasma, are compared with the results obtained for ethanol at 0 osmolality. For example, Fig. 1 shows that 250 mm ethanol in 400 mm stachyose produces a Δ(ΔG) of −300 cal/mol, while in the absence of osmolyte 500 mm ethanol is required to produce this value of Δ(ΔG). The relationship between osmolality and the ethanol dose that is required for an equivalent effect at 0 osmolality is very linear for all of the osmolyte-containing solutions. Therefore, all of the data can be used to determine the effects of 50 and 100 mm ethanol on the MI to MII conformation change at the osmolality of human plasma, 360 mOsm. At this osmolality, 50 mm ethanol would be equivalent to 134 ± 20 mm at 0 osmolality, and 100 mm would be equivalent to 291 ± 12 mm. Thus, at the osmolality of human plasma, the potency of ethanol in the 50–100 mmrange is increased by a factor of 2.7–2.9. Using this potency factor, the substantial changes observed at 0 osmolality with 50 and 100 mm ethanol would be observed at about 18 and 36 mm ethanol, respectively, at the osmolality of plasma. The sensitivity of rhodopsin to changes in membrane composition and phospholipid acyl chain packing is well documented. Hence, it is reasonable to question whether the osmolyte enhancement of the effect of ethanol on MII formation arises through some direct interaction of ethanol on rhodopsin or via a lipid-mediated process induced by increased binding of ethanol to the bilayer. Earlier studies demonstrate that factors that increase K eq(e.g. higher temperature (22.Mitchell D.C. Straume M. Miller J.L. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 9143-9149Crossref PubMed Scopus (148) Google Scholar, 23.Mitchell D.C. Straume M. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 662-670Crossref PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar, 24.Litman B.J. Mitchell D.C. Lipids. 1996; 31 (suppl.): 193Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), increased phospholipid acyl chain unsaturation (23.Mitchell D.C. Straume M. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 662-670Crossref PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar, 24.Litman B.J. Mitchell D.C. Lipids. 1996; 31 (suppl.): 193Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), decreased bilayer cholesterol (22.Mitchell D.C. Straume M. Miller J.L. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 9143-9149Crossref PubMed Scopus (148) Google Scholar, 23.Mitchell D.C. Straume M. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 662-670Crossref PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar)) also increase f v, and changes in K eq and f v are linearly related. Ethanol-induced changes in Δ(ΔG) and Δf v are also linearly related in the absence of osmolyte, as shown in Fig. 5 A. Fig. 4 shows that osmotic stress increases the ability of ethanol to loosen acyl chain packing, as shown by the greater percentage increases in f vwith increasing osmolality for all ethanol concentrations. If all of the ethanol-induced increase in MII formation is due to ethanol-induced changes in acyl chain packing, then the correlation lines in Fig.5 A would be coincident, and increasing osmolality would simply shift each group of points to higher values of Δf v and more negative values of Δ(ΔG). However, marked nonlinearity and deviations from the 0 osmolyte Δ(ΔG) versusΔf v correlation line are observed. A possible interpretation of the nonlinearity seen in Fig.5 A is that it reflects an osmotic stress-dependent component to the enhancement of MII formation by ethanol, which acts in addition to the effect of ethanol on acyl chain packing. This interpretation is consistent with the idea that the basic mechanism whereby ethanol reduces acyl chain packing order in the core of the bilayer is unaltered by osmotic stress. This basic mechanism involves hydrogen bonding to the phospholipid carbonyl oxygen, resulting in increased average phospholipid head group spacing, which induces acyl chain disorder (33.Barry, J. A., and Gawrisch, K. (1994) Biochemistry 8082–8088Google Scholar). The increased ability of ethanol to disorder acyl chain packing with reduced water activity (Figs. 4 and 5 A) is probably due to its enhanced competition with water for this hydrogen bonding site at reduced water activity. The data in Fig. 5 A acquired in the absence of osmotic stress, the 0 osmolyte data, represent the correlation between ethanol-induced changes in the MI-MII equilibrium and ethanol-induced changes in acyl chain packing. It is similar to the linear correlation between these two parameters when both are altered by variation in temperature or bilayer cholesterol content (22.Mitchell D.C. Straume M. Miller J.L. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 9143-9149Crossref PubMed Scopus (148) Google Scholar, 23.Mitchell D.C. Straume M. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 662-670Crossref PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar, 24.Litman B.J. Mitchell D.C. Lipids. 1996; 31 (suppl.): 193Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The 0 osmolyte, Δ(ΔG) versus Δf vcorrelation line can be interpreted as representing the susceptibility of the MI-MII equilibrium to changes in acyl chain packing due to ethanol. This allows the Δ(ΔG) versusΔf v correlation to be used to identify the fraction of the magnified effects of ethanol onK eq, which are due to changes in acyl chain packing. The slope of the 0 osmolyte, Δ(ΔG)versus Δf v correlation line indicates that an ethanol-induced increment in f v of 0.01 will decrease ΔG by 510 cal/mol. By using this relationship, we can examine to what extent the ethanol-induced decreases in ΔG under osmotic stress are attributable to changes in acyl chain packing and thus mediated by the membrane. The extra Δ(ΔG) component under various osmotic conditions corresponds to the deviation of those points on the Δ(ΔG) axis from the 0 osmolyte correlation line in Fig.5 A. The corrected Δ(ΔG) values are shown in Fig. 5 B. The results of this analysis show that under all osmotic conditions and ethanol concentrations examined, the effect of ethanol on ΔG is greater than what would be expected from the ethanol-induced increases in f v, as summarized in Fig. 6. The bars in Fig. 6represent the fraction of ethanol's effect on the MI-MII equilibrium that exceeds the membrane-mediated effect of ethanol. We would assign this component of Δ(ΔG) to a direct effect of ethanol on rhodopsin. Near physiological osmolality, at 330 mOsm, the effect of 50 mm ethanol on the MI-MII equilibrium is ∼90% due to changes in acyl chain packing and ∼10% due to a direct effect of ethanol on rhodopsin (Fig. 6). At all concentrations of ethanol, the fractional contribution of the direct effect of ethanol on rhodopsin increases with osmotic stress. This suggests that osmotic stress enhances the ability of ethanol to act directly on rhodopsin in a way that favors MII formation. It is also observed that at each osmolality the nonbilayer contribution generally decreases with increasing ethanol concentration. One of the proposed mechanisms for the effect of ethanol on receptors is a change in hydrogen-bonded water (1.Eyring H. Woodbury J.W. D'Arrigo J.S. Anesthesiology. 1973; 38: 415-424Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar, 2.Klemm W.R. Alcohol. 1998; 15: 249-267Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). In the absence of ethanol, at 20 °C, an examination of the MI to MII conversion as a function of osmotic stress showed that MII formation results in the net release of 20 ± 1 water molecules. This number increased to 35 water molecules when corrected for bilayer effects (13.Mitchell D.C. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 7617-7623Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). If ethanol perturbs the hydrogen bonding of water to either MI or MII, it should alter the number of water molecules released upon MII formation. The effect of ethanol on ΔN w, the change in the number of water molecules in osmolyte-inaccessible regions, was assessed by analyzing ln(K eq) as a function of osmolality for each concentration of ethanol according to Equation 2 (10.Parsegian V.A. Rand R.P. Rau D.C. Methods Enzymol. 1995; 259: 43-94Crossref PubMed Scopus (372) Google Scholar). The positive, linear correlations in Fig. 7 demonstrate that ethanol has not altered the basic relationship between increased osmolality and increased MII formation that was observed in the absence of ethanol. The values of ΔN w derived from the data in Fig. 7 are 25 ± 3 for 50 mm ethanol, 30 ± 3 mm for 100 mm ethanol, 31 ± 3 for 300 mm ethanol, and 33 ± 4 for 500 mmethanol. In our earlier studies (13.Mitchell D.C. Litman B.J. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 7617-7623Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar), adjusting Δ(ΔG) for bilayer contributions yielded a corrected number of water molecules released upon MII formation. Since both ethanol and osmotic pressure are known to have opposing effects on bilayer acyl chain packing, adjusting Δ(ΔG) for the effect of these agents on the bilayer will again yield corrected numbers of released water molecules. This correction was carried out using Equation 4, as described under “Experimental Procedures,” and results in a net bilayer correction that makes Δ(ΔG) more negative for all osmolalities and ethanol concentrations. This demonstrates that the acyl chain ordering due to increased osmolality outweighs the disordering effect of ethanol, resulting in a net inhibitory contribution of the bilayer to MII formation. Plotting the corrected values of ln(K eq) versus osmolality yields about 49 molecules released upon MII formation for all ethanol concentrations studied. Here, we see that the apparent variation in numbers of released water molecules as a function of ethanol concentration is a reflection of the mixed effect of osmotic pressure and ethanol on bilayer acyl packing and not an inherent property of the system. The increase in ΔN w with added ethanol suggests that ethanol can influence a second population of loosely bound water molecules in MII. Ethanol may replace all or part of this second population of waters in the rhodopsin hydration sphere. This represents a direct effect of ethanol on MII formation, independent of its effect on the phospholipid bilayer. The direct effect of ethanol does not appear to be present in the absence of osmolyte. The formation of MII is accompanied by an increase in hydrogen bonding of one or two internal water molecules (20.Rath P. Delange F. DeGrip W.J. Rothschild K.J. Biochem. J. 1998; 329: 713-717Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar); thus, it is unlikely that the pockets that release water molecules during the MI to MII transition are in the protein interior. The cytoplasmic surface of rhodopsin undergoes significant structural rearrangement between MI and MII, and this is the most likely region to undergo a net loss of water during this transition. The ability of ethanol to increase the number of released water molecules suggests that there are about 15 additional water molecules, which are hydrogen-bonded to the protein in the MI conformation but which may be susceptible to replacement by ethanol in the MII conformation. A conclusion of the present study is that ethanol contributes to an increased loss of water molecules for the MII conformation relative to the MI conformation. Examination of the combined effects of ethanol and osmotic stress on both the MI-MII conformational equilibrium and phospholipid acyl chain packing makes it possible to distinguish between direct effects of ethanol on the receptor and those mediated by the membrane. Increased osmolality enhanced the ethanol-induced broadening of the DPH orientational probability distribution (Fig. 3) and the ethanol-induced increase of the parameter f v (Fig. 4). These observations strongly suggest that a portion of ethanol's enhancement of MII formation is due to increased acyl chain disorder. Prior knowledge of how membrane physical properties are related to MII formation shows that the changes in acyl chain packing are unable to account for all of enhancement of MII by ethanol under conditions of osmotic stress, as shown in Fig. 6. Ethanol increases the number of water molecules released during the MI to MII transition, suggesting that ethanol disrupts protein-water hydrogen bonds during the formation of MII. Thus, by simultaneously measuring changes both in the physical properties of the membrane bilayer and protein function, it was possible to distinguish direct effects of ethanol on the protein and effects of ethanol that are mediated by the membrane. It should be noted that at physiologically relevant ethanol concentrations and osmolalities comparable with human plasma, there is about a 2.8-fold enhancement of the effect of ethanol on MII formation. In addition, about 90% of this enhancement is derived from the effect of ethanol on acyl chain packing in the lipid bilayer. This type of analysis should provide further insight into the effects of drugs and other perturbations on receptors like rhodopsin, which have their agonist/antagonist binding site in a region of the protein, which is within the membrane.

Bis(maleidophenyl)-PEG2000 (Bis-Mal-PEG2000), a new bifunctional protein cross-linker targeted to sulfhydryl groups, introduces intra-tetrameric cross-links into oxy-HbA in nearly quantitative yields. Structural as well as crystallographic analyses of the cross-linked species, Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA, identified Cys-93(β) as the site of intramolecular cross-linking. The cross-bridging had only a limited influence on the O2 affinity and cooperativity of HbA in 50 mm BisTris acetate, pH 7.4. However, the Bohr effect was reduced by ∼60%. Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA retained sensitivity to the presence of allosteric effectors 2,3-diphosphoglycerate, IHP, and chloride, albeit to a lesser degree compared with HbA. Crystallographic analysis revealed the overall structure of deoxy-Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA to be similar to deoxy-HbA but for the loss of the salt bridge between Asp-94(β) and His-146(β). The large influence of the cross-bridging on the alkaline Bohr effect of HbA is consistent with the loss of this salt bridge. Unlike the “central cavity cross-bridges” described previously, the cross-link introduced by Bis-Mal-PEG2000 into HbA is an “outside the central cavity cross-bridge.” In view of its oxy-conformational specificity and limited influence on O2 affinity, this new cross-linking strategy holds promise for the stabilization of new designer low O2 affinity Hbs generated by recombinant DNA technology for applications as Hb based therapeutics. Andracki M.E. Walder J.A. Methods Enzymol. 1994; 231: 274-280Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar). Intramolecularly cross-bridged Hbs are also under very active investigation as potential candidates for Hb-based therapeutics (2.Vandegriff K.D. Biotechnol. Genet. Eng. Rev. 1992; 10: 403-453Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar, 3.Bunn H.F. Am. J. Hematol. 1993; 42: 112-117Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar, 4.Winslow R.M. Winslow R.M. Vandegriff K.D. Intaglietta M. Blood Substitutes: New Challenges. Birkhaeuser Boston, Cambridge, MA1996: 60-73Crossref Google Scholar). Several intramolecular cross-bridging approaches have been developed over the years for the stabilization of Hb tetramer against dissociation into αβ dimers (1.Walder R.Y. Andracki M.E. Walder J.A. Methods Enzymol. 1994; 231: 274-280Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar, 5.Chatterjee R. Welty E.V. Walder R.Y. Pruitt S.L. Rogers P.H. Arnone A. Walder J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 9929-9937Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 6.Snyder S. Welty E.V. Walder R.Y. Williams L.A. Walder J.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 7280-7284Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar, 7.Benesch R.E. Methods Enzymol. 1994; 231: 267-274Crossref PubMed Scopus (5) Google Scholar, 8.Jones R.T. Head C.G. Fujita T.S. Shih D.T.B. Wodzinska J. Kluger R. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 215-223Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar, 9.Bucci E. Razynska A. Kwansa H. Fronticelli C. Artif. Cells Blood Substit. Immobil. Med. 1994; 128: 146-153Abstract Full Text PDF Scopus (46) Google Scholar). By and large, the currently available intramolecular cross-bridging reagents are targeted to the reactive functional groups within the central cavity of Hb in domains that interact with allosteric effectors. In fact, some of the cross-linkers have been designed to mimic the interactions of the allosteric effectors. Their design strategy has focused on the complementarity between the stereochemistry of the tagging ends of the proposed bi- or tri-functional reagents and the reactive functional groups within the central cavity (1.Walder R.Y. Andracki M.E. Walder J.A. Methods Enzymol. 1994; 231: 274-280Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar, 5.Chatterjee R. Welty E.V. Walder R.Y. Pruitt S.L. Rogers P.H. Arnone A. Walder J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 9929-9937Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 6.Snyder S. Welty E.V. Walder R.Y. Williams L.A. Walder J.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 7280-7284Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar, 7.Benesch R.E. Methods Enzymol. 1994; 231: 267-274Crossref PubMed Scopus (5) Google Scholar, 8.Jones R.T. Head C.G. Fujita T.S. Shih D.T.B. Wodzinska J. Kluger R. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 215-223Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar, 9.Bucci E. Razynska A. Kwansa H. Fronticelli C. Artif. Cells Blood Substit. Immobil. Biotechnol. 1994; 22 (abstr.): 84Google Scholar, 10.Bucci E. Razynska A. Kwansa H. Urbaitis B. O'Hearne M. Ulatowski J.A. Koehler C. J. Lab. Clin. Med. 1994; 128: 146-153Abstract Full Text PDF Scopus (46) Google Scholar). In view of their location within the central cavity in the modified Hbs, these cross-links offer steric hindrance for interactions with the allosteric effectors compared with unmodified HbA. An alternate plausible approach to introduce intramolecular cross-bridging into Hb is to place the cross-bridges outside the central cavity, thereby avoiding perturbation of the domains of Hb that interact with allosteric effectors. A number of side chain functional groups (sulfhydryl, amino, and carboxyl groups) of the surface residues of Hb exhibit unusual chemical reactivity toward group-specific reagents (maleimides, aliphatic aldehydes, and carbodiimide-mediated activation of the side chain carboxyl groups in the presence ofN-hydroxysulfosuccinimide, respectively). The site-specific, monofunctional chemical modification approaches developed previously during the structure-function correlation studies of Hb could be adapted with the inclusion of a suitable flexible “spacer group” to develop a new class of outside the central cavity intramolecular cross-linking bifunctional reagents. Accordingly, we have been exploring the design and synthesis of new bifunctional reagents for the intramolecular cross-bridging of Hb outside its central cavity, taking advantage of the unusual chemical reactivity of one or more functional groups located on its surface. We have chosen polyethylene glycol (PEG)1 as the flexible “spacer arm” for this new class of bifunctional reagents. The availability of PEG in well defined molecular sizes will readily permit changing the length of the cross-linker without extensively changing the chemistry for the synthesis of the bifunctional reagent. For our initial evaluation of such an approach, the sulfhydryl group of Cys-93(β) was selected as the target site, because of its unusually high reactivity in the oxy state toward maleimides, and PEG2000 was selected as the spacer group. The maleimide moiety was anchored at either end of the PEG2000 spacer through a phenyl bridge. The structure of the new bifunctional reagent is shown in Fig. 1. In its fully extended form the PEG2000 spacer arm can span a distance of about 115 Å. Molecular modeling of bis(succinimidophenyl)-PEG2000 HbA, the product expected to be generated by the reaction of this reagent with HbA, demonstrated that the flexibility of the spacer arm is more than adequate for the PEG chain to wrap around the Hb molecule after one end of the reagent has reacted with the Cys-93(β) of one αβ dimer to facilitate reaction of the other end of the reagent with the Cys-93(β) of the other αβ dimer, thus achieving intramolecular cross-bridging of HbA outside its central cavity. The success of this new cross-bridging approach and the chemical characterization of this new class of intramolecularly cross-bridged species of HbA as well as its functional and crystallographic analyses are presented here. Human HbA was purified from the erythrocyte lysate, as described earlier (11.Acharya A.S. Sussman L.G. Manning J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 2296-2302Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The synthesis of bis(maleidophenyl)-PEG2000 essentially involves the condensation ofp-maleidophenyl isocyanate (12.Annunziato M.E. Patel U.S. Ranade M. Palumbo P.S. Bioconjugate Chem. 1993; 4: 212-218Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar) with PEG2000. Typically, 100 g of PEG2000 was azeotropically dried with toluene (1.5 liters) and cooled to room temperature under an atmosphere of nitrogen. To this dried PEG solution was added 23 g ofp-maleidophenyl isocyanate (obtained from BioAffinity Systems, Inc., Roscoe, IL), and the solution was reheated to 30–40 °C with stirring for 3 h. The reaction mixture was then filtered and concentrated under vacuum to about 300 ml. Five volumes of anhydrous ethyl ether was added with continuous stirring to the concentrated toluene solution. The resulting yellow precipitate was filtered at the pump, redissolved in 500 ml of anhydrous chloroform, filtered, reprecipitated with five volumes of ethyl ether, and dried to yield 100 g of light yellow solid. Infrared spectra (KBr disc) revealed the carbonyl contributed from the maleimido moiety at 1710 cm−1, which was absent in the spectra of PEG2000. This compound was designated Bis-Mal-PEG2000 (Fig.1). Hemoglobin (0.5 mm) in phosphate-buffered saline, pH 7.4, was reacted with Bis-Mal-PEG2000 at the temperatures and durations indicated in the text at a protein:cross-linker molar ratio of 1:2. The reaction product was dialyzed against 10 mm potassium phosphate, pH 6.5, and subjected to purification on a CM-cellulose column. The globin chains of the various hemoglobin preparations were analyzed by RPHPLC by methods previously described (13.Rao M.J. Schneider K. Chait B.C. Chao T.L. Keller H.L. Anderson S.M. Manjula B.N. Kumar R.A. Acharya A.S. Artif. Cells Blood Substit. Immobil. Biotechnol. 1994; 22: 695-700Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). The formation of oligomeric forms of Hb was evaluated by size exclusion chromatographic analysis of the cross-linked Hb on Superose 12 (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) in 50 mm BisTris, pH 7.4. The formation of intramolecularly cross-linked species was also monitored by size exclusion chromatographic analysis of the cross-linked Hb on the same Superose 12 column but using 50 mm BisTris, pH 7.4, containing 0.9 mMgCl2 as the eluant. Tryptic peptide mapping of the globin samples and NH2-terminal amino acid sequence analysis of the peptides were carried out as described (13.Rao M.J. Schneider K. Chait B.C. Chao T.L. Keller H.L. Anderson S.M. Manjula B.N. Kumar R.A. Acharya A.S. Artif. Cells Blood Substit. Immobil. Biotechnol. 1994; 22: 695-700Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). The -SH content of unmodified and cross-linked Hb was estimated by reaction with 4,4-dithiopyridine (14.Ampulski R.S. Ayers V.E. Morell S.A. Anal. Biochem. 1969; 32: 163-169Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar). Isoelectric focusing and SDS-PAGE analyses were carried out as described previously (15.O'Donnel J.K. Birch P. Parsons C.T. White S.P. Okabe J.F. Martin M.J. Adams C. Sundarapandiyan K. Manjula B.N. Acharya A.S. Logan J.S. Kumar R.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 27692-27699Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Oxygen equilibrium curves for the cross-linked Hb were determined using a Hem-O-Scan (Aminco). Before crystallization, Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA was first stripped of organic and inorganic ions by passing it through a Dintzis column (16.Riggs A. Methods Enzymol. 1981; 76: 5-29Crossref PubMed Scopus (244) Google Scholar) that was modified by adding a 1-mm layer of chelating resin (iminodiacetic acid, Sigma No. C-7901) to the top of the column. Stripped Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA was then concentrated to ∼100 mg/ml and was frozen and stored in liquid nitrogen until being used for crystallization. Crystals of the deoxy-Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA were grown at room temperature according to a batch method with the addition of a seeding step as described previously by Kavanaugh et al. (17.Kavanaugh J.S. Weydert J.A. Rogers P.H. Arnone A. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 4358-4373Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). Specifically, the crystallization conditions were 10 mm potassium phosphate at pH 7.0, 100 mm potassium chloride, 3 mmsodium dithionite, and 10∼12% PEG 6000. Crystals grew in about 4 weeks to a size of 1.0 mm × 1.0 mm × 0.6 mm and were isomorphous with those of deoxy-HbA (18.Kavanaugh J.S. Rogers P.H. Case D.A. Arnone A. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 4111-4121Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar) (space group P21212 with a = 97.4 Å,b = 99.3 Å, and c = 66.1 Å). Diffraction data were collected on a single crystal using a Rigaku AFC6 four-circle diffractometer fitted with a San Diego Multiwire Systems area detector. A total of 244,427 measurements were made of 34,179 unique reflections. All diffraction data were scaled and merged according to the procedure of Howard et al. (19.Howard A.J. Nielson C. Xuong N.H. Methods Enzymol. 1985; 114: 452-472Crossref PubMed Scopus (280) Google Scholar). This data set for deoxy-Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA is 97.5% complete at 2.16 Å and 88.1% complete for the highest resolution shell (2.33 Å–2.16 Å). The R symm value of this data set is 7.3% on intensity. A difference electron density map calculated with (F deoxy-Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA −F deoxy-HbA) amplitudes and phases derived from the refined structure of deoxy-HbA contained three significant features: positive difference density extending from the ends of the Cys-93(β1) and Cys-93(β2) side chains, negative difference density at the positions of Asp-94(β1) and Asp-94(β2) side chains, and negative difference density at the positions of His-146(β1) and His-146(β2) side chains. Based on this information, a starting model for deoxy-Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA was constructed from the refined crystal structure of deoxy-HbA by 1) converting Cys-93(β1) and Cys-93(β2) into alanine residues, 2) converting Asp-94(β1) and Asp-94(β2) into alanine residues, and 3) deleting the last four residues (residues 143–146) of each β subunit. Initial refinement of this model consisted of rigid body refinement with X-PLOR (20.Brunger A.T. X-PLOR, Version 3.1. Yale University Press, New Haven, Connecticut1992Google Scholar) followed by stereochemical-restrained least-square refinement with PROLSQ (21.Hendrick J.P. Hartl F. FASEB J. 1995; 9: 1559-1569Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar). Next, (2F obs − F calc) and (F obs − F calc) electron density maps were used with the TOM/FRODO software (22.Jones T.A. Methods Enzymol. 1985; 115: 157-189Crossref PubMed Scopus (934) Google Scholar) to position the side chains at residues 93(β) and 94(β) and add residues His-143, Lys-144, and Tyr-145 to the β1 and β2 COOH termini. The COOH-terminal residues of both β subunits were built in as alanines because of the complete absence of electron density for the imidazole group of His-146(β). Although the chemical modifications of Cys-93(β1) and Cys-93(β2) are confirmed (see “Results”), the Bis-Mal-PEG2000 cross-linker was not built into the atomic model due to its weak electron density. Final refinement of the atomic model was carried out with PROLSQ. The R andR free values of the refined crystal structure of deoxy-Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA are 17.2 and 23.2%, respectively. This atomic model has good stereochemistry; the root mean square deviation from ideal bond lengths is 0.008 Å, and the root mean square deviation from ideal bond angles is 1.2°. HbA, 0.5 mm in phosphate-buffered saline, pH 7.4, was incubated with a 2-fold molar excess of Bis-Mal-PEG2000 at room temperature for 2 h, and the products of the reaction were analyzed by RPHPLC and size exclusion chromatography. A comparison of the RPHPLC map of the globin chains of Bis-Mal-PEG2000-reacted HbA with that of unreacted HbA revealed that the β-chains of the protein have been quantitatively derivatized (Fig. 2). The modified β-globin eluted at a new position, slightly later than the α-globin. The quantitative modification of the β-chains of HbA on incubation with Bis-Mal-PEG2000, even with only a 2-fold molar excess of the maleimide moiety over the sulfhydryl groups, reflects the high reactivity of the maleimide group of the bifunctional reagent with the -SH groups of the protein. Kinetic studies of this reaction have indicated that the reaction is essentially complete in less than 1 h. Our studies have also indicated that this reaction can be carried out at 4 °C; generally, a longer reaction period was employed at the lower temperature. Analysis of the Bis-Mal-PEG2000 reacted HbA by size exclusion chromatography on a Superose 12 column in 50 mm BisTris-Ac, pH 7.4, revealed that >95% of the protein elutes as a 64,000-dalton species (tetrameric), and only a trace amount is present as the octameric species (Fig. 3 A). Since the β-chains in the Bis-Mal-PEG2000-reacted HbA have been quantitatively derivatized (Fig. 2), the gel filtration data suggested that either each β-chain of the tetramer carries 1 mol of covalently bound polyethylene glycol (i.e. HbA monofunctionally modified by the bifunctional reagent), or the two β-chains of the tetramer are intramolecularly cross-linked. To distinguish between these two possibilities, the Bis-Mal-PEG2000-reacted HbA was analyzed by SEC on the Superose 12 column in the presence of 0.9 mMgCl2 (Fig. 3 B). Under these conditions, control HbA and monofunctionally modified HbA will dissociate into αβ dimers (apparent molecular size of 32,000 daltons), whereas HbA intramolecularly cross-bridged between the like chains will remain a tetramer (64,000 daltons) (23.Macleod R.M. Hill R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1970; 245: 4875-4879Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). As can be seen from Fig. 3 B, in the presence of 0.9 m MgCl2 nearly all of the Bis-Mal-PEG2000-reacted HbA eluted at the 64,000-dalton position, whereas the control HbA was completely dissociated into αβ dimers. Thus, the results of SEC under dissociating and nondissociating conditions together with the results of the RPHPLC analysis of the globin chains suggested stabilization of the hemoglobin tetramer by intramolecular cross-linking of its two β-chains by Bis-Mal-PEG2000. Hence, the modified β-chain in the RPHPLC map of Bis-Mal-PEG2000-reacted HbA (Fig. 2) represents cross-bridged β-chains. The complete absence of the dimeric species in the Bis-Mal-PEG2000-modified HbA, as seen by the SEC analysis under dissociating conditions, indicated that the intra-molecular cross-linking of HbA by Bis-Mal-PEG2000 is essentially quantitative, a result that is consistent with the results of RPHPLC. Further confirmation of the intra-molecular cross-bridging of β-chains in Bis-Mal-PEG2000-reacted HbA was obtained by SDS-PAGE analysis (Fig. 4). Unreacted HbA contained a band at 16,000 daltons corresponding to the α- and the β-chains (Fig. 4, lane B). On the other hand, Bis-Mal-PEG2000-reacted HbA contained a band at 16,000 daltons and an additional band corresponding to an apparent molecular mass of 32,000 daltons (Fig. 4, lanes C). The SDS-PAGE pattern of ββ-sebacyl HbA and αα-fumaryl HbA, two central cavity cross-bridged Hbs, are also shown in Fig. 4 (lanes D andE) for comparison. Like the Bis-Mal-PEG2000-reacted HbA, these central cavity-cross-bridged HbA species do not dissociate into αβ dimers in the presence of 0.9 m MgCl2and contain a 32,000 dalton species. The specificity of the maleimides to the sulfhydryl groups of proteins suggests that the cross-bridging of HbA by Bis-Mal-PEG2000 is through its cysteine residues. This was further confirmed by the observation that HbA preincubated with N-ethylmaleimide, a sulfhydryl reagent, did not form any intramolecularly cross-bridged species on reaction with Bis-Mal-PEG2000 (data not shown). The Bis-Mal-PEG2000-reacted HbA was subjected to purification on a CM-cellulose column (Fig. 5). Consistent with the RPHPLC analysis, the Bis-Mal-PEG2000-reacted HbA did not contain any unreacted HbA. All of the modified HbA eluted slightly ahead of HbA as a single symmetrical peak, demonstrating homogeneity of the reaction product. The protein was pooled as indicated in the figure, concentrated, and designated as Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA. The isoelectric point of the purified Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA was nearly the same as the parent-unmodified HbA (Fig. 5, inset A), demonstrating that the intramolecular cross-linking has very little influence on the overall ionization behavior of the protein. SEC analysis of the purified Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA in the presence of MgCl2 reconfirmed the stabilization of its tetrameric structure against dissociation by intramolecular cross-linking (Fig. 5, inset B). Estimation of the sulfhydryl groups revealed the presence of two reactive -SH groups in oxy-HbA and its total absence in oxy-Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA (data not shown). Tryptic peptide map of the cross-linked β-globin revealed the presence of a new peptide that eluted around 80 min (Fig.6). Amino acid sequence analysis of this new peptide confirmed it to be the β-chain region corresponding to residues 83–104 (data not shown), except for the fact that no amino acid could be detected in the eleventh cycle. This position corresponds to that of Cys-93(β), suggesting that this residue is modified in the new peptide. Thus, it is clear that Bis-Mal-PEG2000 has covalently bridged the two Cys-93(β) residues of HbA, thereby stabilizing its tetrameric structure against dissociation. A comparison of the oxygen binding properties of Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA and control HbA, measured in 50 mm BisTris acetate, pH 7.4, at 37 °C, is shown in Fig. 7. As can be seen, the intramolecular cross-bridging has induced only a negligible left shifting of the O2 affinity of HbA. Furthermore, analysis of the Hill plot (Fig. 7, inset) revealed that the cooperativity of the cross-linked protein remains essentially the same as the control HbA. In addition to 50 mm BisTris acetate, pH 7.4, the O2 affinity of Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA was also determined in three other buffers, namely 50 mm HEPES, pH 7.4, 50 mm phosphate, pH 7.4, and 50 mm BisTris, 50 mm Tris acetate, pH 7.4. As can be seen in TableI, the increase in O2affinity of Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA relative to control HbA was only marginal in the BisTris acetate buffer, whereas it was somewhat higher in the other three buffers. As can be seen from Table I, the O2 affinity of HbA is significantly lower (higher P50) in the HEPES, phosphate, and BisTris-Tris acetate buffers relative to the BisTris acetate buffer, whereas that of Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA remained essentially the same in all the four buffers. Thus, the relatively higher left-shifting of the O2 affinity of Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA in the former buffers is a reflection of the propensity of these buffers to reduce the O2 affinity of unmodified HbA but not that of the cross-linked HbA. The influence of intramolecular cross-bridging on the O2 affinity of HbA was also measured as a function of pH in the range of pH 6.0 to 8.0 in 50 mm BisTris, 50 mm Tris acetate as well as in 100 mm phosphate buffer (Fig.8). At all the pHs investigated, both HbA and Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA exhibited a lower oxygen affinity in phosphate buffer compared with that in BisTris-Tris acetate buffer. However, at all the pHs examined, the lowering of O2 affinity of Bis-Mal-PEG2000-HbA by phosphate was significantly smaller than that observed with HbA. The Bohr effect of HbA is around 0.43 in both the BisTris-Tris acetate and the phosphate buffers. The Bohr effect in both the buffers is considerably lowered on Bis-Mal-PEG2000 cross-linking of HbA. The Bohr effect is 0.17 in the BisTris-Tris acetate buffer and is 0.13 in the phosphate buffer. Thus, the cross-bridging has drastically reduced the propensity of the protein to transition into a low O2affinity structure as the pH is lowered from the neutral pH. A structural consequence of lowering the pH is protonation of the ionizable functional groups of Hb with pK a around neutral pH. This protonation can modulate the electrostatic interactions of the protein and is translated as a lowered O2 affinity of the heme site. The Bis-Mal-PEG2000 cross-bridging has reduced the protonation effect on the O2affinity of the HbA. This could be a consequence of a change in the pK a of a residue or sensitivity of the cross-bridged protein to the protonation effect. The propensity of allosteric effectors to reduce the O2 affinity of Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA was determined in 50 mm BisTris-Ac buffer, pH 7.4 (TableII). Like HbA, Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA was also sensitive to the presence of DPG and IHP. However, the response of the cross-linked HbA to these effectors was diminished relative to HbA. Consistent with the solution studies described above, electron density images of the regions surrounding Cys-93(β) (Figs. 9,A and B) clearly show that this residue is chemically modified. Although the ends of the Bis-Mal-PEG2000 cross-link can be seen (Fig. 9 B), there is very little significant electron density for the remainder of the molecule. Since the sulfhydryl groups of Cys-93(β)s are located near the protein surface, it was expected that the intramolecular cross-linker would be fully exposed to solvent. The lack of electron density supports this conjecture and indicates that the middle part of the Bis-Mal-PEG2000 cross-link is highly disordered. Moreover, the Bis-Mal-PEG2000 cross-link appears to be long and flexible enough to allow the binding of DPG (see above) despite the fact that the cross-linker must extend over (or in the vicinity of) the DPG binding site to bridge the two Cys-93(β)s. Our x-ray diffraction analysis also reveals that the salt bridge present in the deoxy-HbA structure between the side chains of Asp-94(β) and His-146(β) is disrupted in deoxy-Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA. Specifically, the covalent linking of Bis-Mal-PEG2000 to Cys-93(β) results in the complete disappearance of the electron density associated with the side chains of Asp-94(β) and His-146(β) (Figs.9, A and B), indicating that both side chains are displaced as a consequence of the chemical modification. The displacement of these side chains is clearly due to steric collision between the cross-linker and the side chain atoms of Asp-94(β) and His-146(β). Relative to deoxy-HbA, the main chain atoms of the β COOH-terminal dipeptides (residues Tyr-145(β) and His-146(β)) of deoxy-Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA move by ∼0.5 Å. Furthermore, an approximately 2-fold increase in the average main chain atomic temperature factors of these regions with respect to deoxy-HbA is also observed. Thus, the backbone atoms of the β COOH-terminal dipeptides have higher mobility in deoxy-Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA relative to HbA. These influences are likely due to the combined effects of the presence of cross-linker and the loss of the intra-subunit salt bridge between Asp-94(β) and His-146(β). Consistent with the crystal structure of des-His-146(β) deoxyhemoglobin (24.Bettati S. Kwiatkowsko L.D. Kavanaugh J.S. Mozzarelli A. Arnone A. Rossi G.L. Noble R.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 33077-33084Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar), in which the salt bridge between Asp-94(β) and His-146(β) is also absent, no significant increase in the mobility is detected for the phenol group of Tyr-145(β) despite a small repositioning of this side chain. With the exception of the tertiary structure changes described above, the overall tertiary and quaternary structures of deoxy-Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA are almost identical to the T conformation of deoxy-HbA. In particular, the intersubunit salt bridge between the His-146(β) carboxyl group and Lys-40(α) side chain is still present in deoxy-Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA, and the phenol group of Tyr-145(β) remains in its binding pocket between Cys-93(β), Pro-100(β), and the backbone carbonyl of Val-98(β). It is well known that crystals of deoxy-HbA disorder when they are exposed to air (25.Haurowitz F.Z. Physiol. Chem. 1938; 254: 268-274Crossref Scopus (69) Google Scholar, 26.Anderson L. J. Mol. Biol. 1973; 79: 495-502Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar), a phenomenon associated with the large ligand-induced structural transition in HbA. However, it has been observed that the deoxy crystals of some high affinity mutant hemoglobins that have greatly reduced cooperativity continue to diffract x-rays after they are exposed to air (27.Kavanaugh J.S. Rogers P.H. Arnone A. Am. Crystallographic Assoc. Annual Meeting, St. Louis, MO, July 19–25. 1997; 24 (abstr.): 93-94Google Scholar). Our studies also indicated that, like the deoxy-HbA crystals, the crystals of deoxy-Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA disorder upon exposing to air, thus supporting the conclusion that the cooperativity and the ligand-induced allosteric transition are not affected by the Bis-Mal-PEG2000 cross-linking. The data presented in this study reveal that Bis-Mal-PEG2000 introduces intra-tetrameric cross-linking between the two β-chains of HbA and, thus, stabilizes the protein against dissociation into dimers. This intra-tetrameric cross-linking reaction is extremely facile, quantitative even with only a 2-fold molar excess of the reagent, and goes to completion within 2 h at room temperature. Chemical characterization has confirmed that the cross-bridging is at the two Cys-93(β) residues. Thus, Bis-Mal-PEG2000 stabilizes the tetrameric structure of HbA by site-specific intramolecular cross-bridging outside its central cavity. Some of the advantages of Bis-Mal-PEG2000 intramolecular cross-bridging reaction are: 1) oxy conformation specificity of the reaction, 2) mild reaction conditions of short duration, and 3) nearly quantitative cross-linking. Furthermore, the reaction is highly site-specific, since it is targeted to the -SH groups of the protein. The site specificity is further enhanced by the fact that there are only three -SH groups per αβ dimer, of which only the β93 -SH group is highly reactive in the oxy conformation. Thus, there is only one reactive site per αβ dimer. In addition, despite its large size, the Bis-Mal-PEG2000 reagent itself is of defined size. The high specificity of the reagent combined with its defined size facilitates the generation of a homogeneous product. The modification of HbA at Cys-93(β) with Bis-Mal-PEG2000 had only a limited influence on its O2 affinity at neutral pH, and the modified protein retained a cooperativity comparable with native HbA. However, the modified protein exhibited a reduced sensitivity of its O2 affinity to buffer ions and allosteric effectors and a reduced Bohr effect. Crystallographic analysis revealed that, with the exception of the loss of the salt bridge between His-146β and Asp-94β, the overall tertiary as well as the quaternary structures of deoxy-Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA are almost identical to the T-conformation of deoxy-HbA, an observation that is consistent with the high cooperativity of the modified protein. In a recent study, Gottfriedet al. (28.Gottfried D.S. Juszczak L.J. Fataliev N.A. Acharya A.S. Hirsch R.E. Friedman J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 1571-1578Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar) observe that carbonmonoxy-Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA shows a significant increase in the binding for a fluorescent analog of DPG, suggesting that the ββ cleft of this cross-bridged HbA is either more open or more flexible relative to that in carbonmonoxy-HbA. Thus, although generated under oxy conformation conditions, the Bis-Mal-PEG2000 cross-bridging of HbA has induced deoxy-like features into the protein. The slightly higher O2 affinity of Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA and the reduced sensitivity of the O2affinity to the various effectors, despite the more deoxy-like features of its ββ cleft in the oxy conformation, suggest that in the absence of the -SH groups of Cys-93(β), the deoxy-like structure of the DPG pocket is not coupled to the heme pocket. Luisi and Nagai (29.Luisi B.F. Nagai K. Nature. 1986; 320: 555-556Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar) report the crystallographic structure of Hb-Nympheas, a Cys-93(β) → Ser mutant of HbA. At neutral pH, Hb-Nympheas (Cys-93β → Ser) has an O2 affinity in 50 mm BisTris, 50 mm Tris, 100 mm HCl, slightly increased over reconstituted HbA, with a cooperativity comparable with the latter (30.Nagai K. Perutz M.F. Poyart C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci., U. S. A. 1985; 82: 7252-7255Crossref PubMed Scopus (181) Google Scholar). Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA described in the present study appears to be similar to Hb-Nympheas with respect to O2 affinity and cooperativity. However, Hb-Nympheas and Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA differ in their response to DPG. Hb-Nympheas exhibits a normal DPG response, whereas Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA exhibits a reduced DPG response. These results suggest that the -SH group of Cys-93(β) of HbA and the -OH group of Ser-93(β) of Hb-Nympheas probably play a nearly similar structural role in facilitating the coupling of the interaction of DPG at the ββ cleft, i.e.the deoxy-like features of the ββ cleft, to the heme site. In contrast, the structural consequences of converting the -SH group into an S-succinimidyl derivative in Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA are quite distinct. Crystallographic analysis of deoxy-Hb-Nympheas has indicated that Asp-94(β) has moved closer to Ser-93(β) and forms a hydrogen bond with the -OH group of Ser-93(β), which is in equilibrium with the normal salt bridge between Asp-94(β) and His-146(β). In contrast, this salt bridge between Asp-94(β) and His-146(β) has disappeared in the crystal structure of Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA. This result suggests that the translation of the electrostatic interactions at the ββ cleft as lowered O2 affinity of the heme requires the integrity of the salt bridge between Asp-94(β) and His-146(β). Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA is quite distinct from the other intramolecularly cross-bridged Hbs reported to date and represents a new class of intramolecularly cross-bridged Hb. It is the first β93β93 intramolecularly cross-bridged species reported to date. The previously described bisdibromosalicyl derivatives of aliphatic carboxylic acids and the bispyridoxal phosphates stabilize the tetrameric structure of HbA by cross-linking the amino groups within its central cavity (1.Walder R.Y. In contrast, Bis-Mal-PEG2000 stabilized the tetrameric structure of Hb by cross-bridging two reactive surface residues on the β-chains that are outside the central cavity of the molecule. Accordingly, we refer to this ββ-cross-bridged species as “outside the central cavity” intramolecularly cross-bridged Hb to distinguish it from the central cavity cross-bridged Hbs. In the central cavity cross-bridged Hbs, the spacer arm is short and is occupying the central cavity. On the other hand, the long flexible spacer arm of the cross-bridge in Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA projects into the solvent and does not occupy the central cavity. Thus, despite intramolecular ββ-cross-linking, the central cavity of Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA is open for interaction with the allosteric effectors. Bis-Mal-PEG2000 HbA differs, therefore, from the previously described ββ-cross-linked Hbs, namely ββ-fumaryl, ββ-sebacyl, and ββ-bispyridoxal tetraphosphate HbAs, having cross-bridges within the ββ-cleft of the central cavity that almost completely block the action of allosteric effectors like DPG. Thus, the “outside the central cavity”-cross-bridging approach described in the present study could be of potential value for the generation of new Hb-based therapeutics.

At the late phase of megakaryocytopoiesis, megakaryocytes undergo endomitosis, which is characterized by DNA replication without cell division. Although a number of cell cycle regulatory molecules have been identified, the precise roles of these molecules in megakaryocytic endomitosis are largely unknown. In a human interleukin-3-dependent cell line transfected with the thrombopoietin (TPO) receptor c-mpl(F-36P-mpl), either treatment with TPO or the overexpression of activated ras (Ha-RasG12V) induced megakaryocytic maturation with polyploid formation. We found that TPO stimulation or Ha-RasG12V expression led to up-regulation of cyclin D1, cyclin D2, and cyclin D3 expression. In addition, expression levels of cyclin A and cyclin B were reduced during the total course of both TPO- and Ha-RasG12V-induced megakaryocytic differentiation, thereby leading to decreased cdc2 kinase activity. Neither the induced expression of cyclin D1, cyclin D2, or cyclin D3 nor the expression of a dominant negative form of cdc2 alone could induce megakaryocytic differentiation of F-36P-mpl cells. In contrast, overexpression of dominant negative cdc2 together with cyclin D1, cyclin D2, or cyclin D3 facilitated megakaryocytic differentiation in the absence of TPO. These results suggest that both D-type cyclin expression and decreased cdc2 kinase activity may participate in megakaryocytic differentiation.
